review: I found the show to be fantastic, only ruined by the horrible VIP acting.

My God the actors who potrayed the VIP people cannot act. I cringed everytime they said a line. It felt like they were just reading them. Even the intonation was off. It was like when we were kids and had to read a play in class and we exagerated the intonation. Terrible, just awful.

Seriously. All things considered, they're a pretty small and self-contained part. The main characters were brilliant in their roles. I guess good actors figured that having parts where they're wearing masks the whole time wouldn't get them much exposure. The pacing and character development were superb.

The VIPs once again are execreble actors. The gravitas and emotion of the show are turned farcical as soon as these rejects from every grade 7 play start talking. Even their gestures are cringe worthy. Non English speaking directors can not distinguish bad acting from good in foreign actors. Test this theory on any film made anywhere at any time in a non English speaking country, which contains an "American" in it. Japanese flicks are notorious for this, even Kurosawa. Break out the ham. I can imagine the ads run in Seoul papers: "Foreign English speaking actors needed." And since last time I checked Seoul isn't L. A., the pool of trained, good, professional actors must run at about ZERO candidates. Show is great otherwise: The contrast between the quality of acting in these cheesy foreigners and the Korean cast couldn't be more obvious. LA London Toronto and Vancouver have loads of actors serving table who would be great. Think about it guys.

Just watched whole 9 episodes and my favorite was the 6th, Gganbu. Not perfect nor a masterpiece, but this is very well made and provides a certain level of emotional experience. The overall show was far beyond things that were shown in trailer. Very well directed, performed, and finding its own unique points from the genre mixture of various references such as Gambling Apocalypse : Kaiji, Battle Royale, and so on. Just hope all others enjoy this show not only in Korea but also everywhere!  Ps. Even to Korean ears, VIPs' English conversations were not well written nor performed. I think the drama could stand well enough without their presence and save the budget.

After hearing about all the hype and seeing it was one of the most watched series in the entire world I finally found time to watch Squid Game. I have to admit that I had fun watching it and was very entertained throughout the entire season. It's about hundreds of contestants (who are all down on their luck and need money) that are asked to play children's games for an shot at winning a lot of money, 45.6 billion won (about 33 million dollars). The only thing is these children games are now all deadly and the last contestant standing wins all the money. It will pull you into its world and before you know it you'll be hooked. It's a thriller with lots of twists and lots of violence. This is a show that will stay in your mind long after you watched it. I know it's already been renewed for another seasons so I hope they can keep the same magic they had for season one.

Comparisons to Season 1 are nonsensical. Season 1 was an original concept that stood and succeeded on its own, which cannot be the case for subsequent seasons.  The best thing about Season 2 is the acting. The cast is absolutely great! Where Squid Game 2 feels lacking, is in its refusal to resolve ANY of the multiple threads in this season. There are many ways to build suspense, but the laziest one is where you just refuse to answer any questions you raised for an entire seasons, leaving it to be addressed in Season 3. It is quite evident that the show is now a lot less interested in telling a satisfying story and more invested in stretching the franchise into a multi-season subscription-retention machine.

For someone who has seen Alice in Borderland and loved it, I see this series as a more mature and rawer version, without fantasies. Criticism of the capitalism of today's society, ironic how it turned out, becoming everything it criticized.  Decent 8/10.

I think it's really good show but the VIP acting is horrible. Seems rushed and no quality.  Slowness to find Truth on the boat team.  Very rushed acting and quality. Looks like Ai is playing big part of it.  When Squid Game premiered on Netflix in 2021, it quickly became a global phenomenon-and for good reason. The South Korean series, created by Hwang Dong-hyuk, is more than just a dystopian survival drama. It's a razor-sharp commentary on capitalism, human behavior, and the moral cost of desperation. While many have already praised its thrilling plot and visual style, Squid Game stands out for its meticulous attention to quality-both in storytelling and production.

Squid Game. Wow.  Korean.  Best description? Uncomfortably genius!  (Kind of disturbing - small warning but still)  I mean there are some elements of The Game and Hunger Games, but this is bigger, more catastrophic in a different way, more clever, plays on psychological aspects, with a touch of closeness between some participants. Its intensely catchy and totally insane.  Its set in a today's society with participants being people in economic trouble who owes a lot of money, mostly from gambling, and about their desperation. Great actors too!!  They even include a very dark business of todays world - but I wont reveal anything here.  Although its brutal - its more brutal in what's actually going on, and what's happening - than being graphically brutal.  And you will sit there and feel lots of things - scared and somewhat freaked out as well, and as I said: its Uncomfortably geniusly made in my opinion.  If you're looking for something different that will get your HR rising, try this one! *Handclaps*

There will be great division on the success of the latest seasons. The writer himself confessed he intended Squid Games to be a 1 season work (One of the greatest seasons in modern television history).  Netflix capitalised on the global success of season 1 and understandably the writer wanted his pay day. And so, Season 2 and 3 was born.  These are at best, filler seasons. They give you very little new revelation, and story loses its focus and there are many wasted character arcs.  I liked moments in Season 2 (for example the round and round we go episode was EPIC). But most of the shock is lost as Season 1 was both the origin and peak of the entire franchise.  I'm grateful that Season 1 can be watched in its entirety as a standalone season. And you can just leave S2 and 3 at the door if you choose. I'm grateful this show was created, despite it now turning into a never ending cash cow for Netflix.
Just binged the whole 9 episodes, best thing I've seen on Netflix since I opened my account. Even though it's dubbed, you hardly notice! Watch it, you won't be disappointed! 👍👍👍

One of the best K Netflix series I've seen in recent years. The plot, cinematography, and acting (with the exception of some masked caucasians in the end) was superb. Several A-list actors were in this show and the cameos by them were very well woven into the story. Looking forward to a season 2.

Season 1 was truly a groundbreaking experience. There is definitely the masterpiece in the Korean cinematography and if you are after Korean style of cinema, S1 is definitely for you.  If you prefer to have everything as a "happy end" and closed story which appears more in American movies, S2 and S3 are for you.  All seasons can be described as 9 to 5. The first season is something that you thrive to watch and know how the final episode will look like. Season 2 is a replica of S1, good enough to watch but once you experienced the original, you are not satisfied with the continuation. S3 is the last hope that producers may bounce back and create something unique and unusual, which is the signature of the series. However, last 2 episodes have been watched with a face-palm face as you can see that producers wanna end the show in a Hollywood fashion.  In short, S1 is the only part you should watch.
I loved it but three last episodes killed the vibe.

We waited 3 or something years for season two to be released (I don't even remember how long, too long) and we get only seven, yes SEVEN episodes, it's ridiculous. Story is so boring and drags at the beginning too much and too many episodes before something will happen. Only thing I like is the characters they are likeable, you really care who survives and who not, but that's all. They talk too much during the games, stop cheering and so on and there is no way they would finish the games in real time, it's like time stops all the time to wait the conversations to end in the games. You can even see in the second game when there is time left 6 seconds(clock on the wall) and they stop moving, starts talking and when they are finished talking they keep moving and pass the finish line  It's just ridiculous that they cut season 2 and 3 in half and we have to wait maybe whole year for the next season, AGAIN!? Yes it's about to get more money but it's just ridiculous.  Maybe squid game lost its hype because of this ridiculously long waiting for the next season, but I'm not impressed at the moment after these SEVEN episodes.  Streaming era is just stupid, you age 10 years if you want to watch one show from the beginning to the end and that's maybe 2-4 seasons(7-10 episodes/season). Bring back tv era and 20 episode seasons, thanks.  How many time I said ridiculous? Yes but it's ridiculous.

Would rate first season as 9/10, second and third - 5 or 6 max. Doesn't worth watching after first, it's nothing like first season, completely pointless things and undeveloped plot and characters, supposedly just to earn more money from a famous tv show.  Flat characters and not logical character decisions, even games from squid games slowly disappeared to be pure killing and betrayal.  With all that depth and idea that first season had, was touching, interesting, when you deeply cared about characters, somehow they did typical low budget show when you are tired already being disappointed of obvious bad, stupid character decisions that couldn't take place. Flat characters was biggest disappointment and made feeling of wasted time.

This is another perfect example of why some great TV series should not keep running just to try and make more money. The first series is simply amazing, the second series is meh and the third series is poor.  I am also not sure why the actors that play the VIPS are such terrible actors, its really odd & thier acting seems to get worse as the series progresses.  Over all its a good phsycological drama, yes its over the top violent and a lot of exageration and although I would say it tends to side with the bad in humans much more than the good people that are out there. Its still a decent series to watch just maybe just watch series one and end it there.

I could've given this 10 but the VIPs ruined this for me. Why the need to add non Korean actors who are so bad at acting? Their sudden appearance in the show threw me off. I didn't know English speaking can be so cringy at such a masterpiece. There was no need to add foreigners, especially ones who are really bad actors. No offense, I'm not one to discrimate any color, but I swear those VIPs don't blend in. I normally like diversity in shows and like seeing a mix of differemt cultures but come on! Totally unecessary on squid game! It ruined this masterpiece! Also, the AI baby is too obvious though I understand it's best to use AI baby than a real one.

The first season of Squid Game was nothing short of groundbreaking, earning a well-deserved 9/10. It introduced a rich tapestry of characters, with Kang Sae-byeok and Song Gi-hun standing out as particularly memorable. The script masterfully balanced suspense and emotional storytelling, making viewers deeply invested in the characters' fates. The "games" were not only creative and thrilling but also served as a sharp critique of societal structures, keeping audiences hooked from start to finish.  Unfortunately, the second season was a significant letdown, feeling like a pseudo-disaster in comparison. The script was riddled with illogical moments, and the plot lacked depth, becoming one of the most boring narratives I've ever watched. Character development was virtually nonexistent, with the main character devolving into a dull, idiotic, and delusional shadow of their former self. The acting ranged from mediocre to outright poor, further diminishing the season's impact.  The games, once the heart-pounding highlight of the series, were uninspired and poorly executed, lacking the cinematic flair that made the first season unforgettable. It felt as though the creators had run out of ideas, delivering a predictable and frustratingly shallow storyline.  While the first season showcased the best of Squid Game's potential, the second tarnished its legacy. I've tried to overlook the second season's flaws, but its glaring issues make it hard to hold onto my initial admiration. What once felt like a solid 9/10 show now struggles to even reach a 7/10. The magic of Squid Game was in its originality and emotional resonance, and the second season failed to capture either.

Season 1 was amazing. It had intense games, emotional stories, and powerful messages about society. Naturally, I was really excited for Season 2, but it didn't live up to my expectations.  The story in Season 2 feels weaker. It tries to expand the world, but it doesn't have the same emotional impact or smart storytelling as the first season. The new characters aren't as memorable, and even the returning ones don't have the same depth or connection to the audience.  The pacing is also a problem. Some parts drag on too long, while others feel rushed. The games are still creative and the visuals are stunning, but it's not enough to make up for the messy story.  Season 2 feels like it's trying too hard to be bigger and more exciting, but it loses the heart and tension that made the first season so special. While there are a few good moments, overall, it's a letdown compared to Season 1.

Honestly wow - from the first episode I sat wide mouthed, what am I watching and why - I didn't care.  This series is amazing, it's brutal, it made me cry - what a watch.  Suddenly you don't care about the subtitles, they pale into nothing, they don't matter - you find yourself watching this, reading effortlessly.  An amazing series, thank you!
Please remove all traces of the VIPs and you can get the 2 stars back.

Was released today and I was hooked by the first 20 minutes. I finished it all the same day , if there was more seasons I would've been watching the next episodes as I'm typing this up right now. Very good series that will have you at the edge of your seat with many twists and turns. Once you think you know what's coming next , it hits you with a curveball. Highly recommended .  You can watch this in one day easily as I did & it was just released a couple hours ago haha .

This show is the best versions of a genre which has been done before. It's just unbelievably aesthetic, gripping and full of suspense. Some episodes are funny and some are very heavy. The season ending is perfect and fulfilling.

When I first saw the trailer, I knew I would watch this show in one day. It is a nice thriller drama that kept me hook throughout. The games that were played and the relationships between the characters is what got me into this show even more. Ending was somewhat predictable, but it was still a good show to watch. I do recommend for you to watch it.

Season 1 of Squid Game was lightning in a bottle. The acting? Phenomenal. Every character-from Gi-hun's desperate charm to Sang-woo's moral decay-was beautifully written and emotionally gripping. You felt their pain, their dilemmas, their slow unraveling. The pacing hit just right, giving room to breathe in emotional moments and ratcheting tension during the games. It didn't treat the audience like toddlers-it trusted us to pick up on themes without spoon-feeding them. The story was unique, bold, and devastatingly human.  Then came Season 2.  Where do I even begin?  The writing nosedived into the realm of forced exposition. Characters didn't speak-they explained. Every philosophical idea was shoved in our faces through clunky, unnatural dialogue, often delivered by minor characters who felt like they were auditioning for a late-night sitcom. The emotional weight that grounded Season 1? Gone. The new characters are flat, unearned, and awkwardly placed into scenes that serve the plot, not the story. The acting-surprisingly-was a shadow of its former self, even from actors who shined in S1.  The pacing was chaos. Important events were either dragged out or dropped in randomly without balance or emotional setup. It felt like the writers had a checklist of plot points and just shoved the characters through them, regardless of logic or consistency. And the philosophical themes? Instead of emerging from the story, they were thrown in as surface-level, pseudo-intellectual lines you forget five minutes later.  Season 2 didn't just stumble-it betrayed what made Season 1 a masterpiece.  Here's hoping Squid Game: America with David Fincher brings back the nuance, tension, and respect for its audience that the original once mastered.

Squid Game is a brilliant metaphor for several things, but especially capitalism. 456 broken and bankrupt rats are set on a deadly race for a vast prize in an absurd and cartoonish version of hell. And who would willingly leave hell if there was even a chance, however outlandish, that staying might suddenly make them a billionaire? Very little of this series otherwise makes sense, and it makes an absolute meal of it.  There are similarities to shows like Battle Royale or Alice in Borderland, but Squid Game does a much better job of making characters believable and likeable. Even passing characters feel like actual people, so you care for the thirty seconds or so that you get to know them before they pass.  The design of the show is brilliant, the performances are all excellent. The danger feels real and the jokes are genuinely funny. I'm only on episode 2, but I love this show already. Personally, I like it better than Alice in Borderland.  EDIT: Just very quickly, a lot of reviews on here are mentioning the cringeworthy acting and dialogue of the VIPs. I agree, but I think there must be a reason for this. It seems unlikely that the same people who cast, wrote and directed all the other terrific performances suddenly lost the ability to cast, write for and direct non-Koreans. It seems more likely their relative cartoonishness had a specific meaning and purpose... even if we haven't figured out what it is, yet.

I started it in 2021 the year it came out and it was a big hit and it got popular around the world, so I was surprised of the success and when I watched it i was very interested to see how it went, i love the drama and the story of the game and the characters in the series and the last three episodes of season one really made me feel emotional, so i was so excited to see the second season but they took a lot of time to make it and now in the last December they just released it and I watched it, it was perfect and I loved it so much and I just released that the show got even bigger than the first season, i am happy to live with this franchise and i am so excited for season three and sadly it will be the last season hope they do well in the next chapter, see you in june 26.( also i will graduate yaaay🔥✨)

"Very Disheartening to See How They Spoiled the Show in the End" - A Reflection on Squid Game Season 3  There are few shows in recent memory that managed to grip the global audience with such ferocity as Squid Game. When Season 1 premiered, it was revolutionary-a bold, brutal, and heart-wrenching social commentary that took us deep into the darkest corners of human nature. It wasn't just a Korean drama; it was a mirror to society's obsession with wealth, power, and survival. Naturally, expectations were sky-high for its future seasons. Unfortunately, after watching Season 3, I can't help but feel deeply disappointed.  To say the show was spoiled in the end feels like an understatement. It's disheartening to see how something so powerful, raw, and emotionally intelligent was reduced to a shell of its former self. The final episodes of Season 3 felt rushed, forced, and frankly, unnecessary. Where there was once soul, now remains only spectacle. It seems the creators were more focused on topping the shock value of previous seasons rather than staying true to the show's original essence.  What made Squid Game iconic wasn't just its gruesome games or the cliffhangers. It was the storytelling-the human moments, the characters you couldn't help but root for, and the gut-wrenching moral dilemmas that left you questioning what you would do in their shoes. In Season 3, much of that depth was lost. Characters were introduced with potential, only to be killed off meaninglessly. Plot twists felt unearned. And the ending... it lacked both closure and clarity, leaving more frustration than intrigue.  Gi-hun's journey, which had once been the emotional anchor of the series, felt completely derailed. His motivations in this season were inconsistent, and his arc, which once symbolized hope and resistance, was reduced to impulsive actions with little emotional payoff. It was like watching a completely different character. One can only assume this was done to leave room for future spin-offs or tie-ins, but it came at the cost of character integrity.  Another issue that stood out was the over-reliance on international elements and forced global appeal. What started as a proudly Korean story steeped in cultural nuances began to lose its authenticity. The deeper philosophical undertones were overshadowed by unnecessary subplots and flashy sequences meant to keep the viewers "entertained." But in doing so, the show lost its heart. The message got diluted.  Perhaps the biggest letdown was the finale itself. A show like Squid Game deserved an ending that left viewers contemplating, mourning, and reflecting. Instead, we were given an ambiguous, almost nonsensical conclusion that felt more like a setup for another season than a satisfying resolution to the journey we've been on for three seasons. It felt like the creators forgot why we fell in love with the show in the first place.  It's always tough to watch a show you once loved take a turn like this. There's a kind of grief attached to it-the grief of lost potential, of characters who deserved better, and of a story that could have been a masterpiece from start to finish. Season 3 had glimpses of brilliance, moments where the original magic tried to shine through. But ultimately, it couldn't escape the weight of its own ambition.  In the end, Squid Game Season 3 didn't feel like the conclusion to a powerful story. It felt like a betrayal of everything it once stood for. And that is what hurts the most.

Squid Game Season 2 fails to live up to the thrilling and thought-provoking storytelling of its predecessor. The season is bogged down by a sluggish pace, with much of its runtime dedicated to tedious setup rather than engaging character development or exciting twists. While the game sequences retain some of the tension and creativity that made the first season a global phenomenon, they are too few and far between to salvage this installment.  One glaring flaw comes in Episode 7 at 22:39, where the cameraman is clearly visible. This kind of oversight is unprofessional and detracts from the immersion of the series, a surprising lapse for a show of this caliber.  The "season" ends abruptly, with little resolution, clearly designed as a prelude to Season 3. This approach feels more like an extended prologue than a full-fledged season, leaving viewers frustrated and unfulfilled. Instead of being marketed as Season 2, it might have been more honest to call it Part 1 of a two-part continuation.  Fans of Squid Game deserved more than a drawn-out buildup with minimal payoff. While the production values remain high, such missteps make this season feel like a wasted opportunity. Here's hoping Season 3 can redeem it.

This show is amazing from action scenes, to thriller, horror, cliffhangers. ALL THE ABOVE this show has it all. It's mysterious I highly recommend it. It can get violent and some nude scenes but a great show. Only thing I do not like about the show is the dubbed version it sounds a little funny. But can't help it it's just Korean. No big deal besides that no complaints this show gets better and better each episode hope season 3 is just as good as the rest of them are. The acting is 10/10 writing 9/10 story 9/10 overall the story and show is a masterpiece and highly recommend it if your a big thriller fan 10/10.

Saying it exceeded expectations isn't really saying much because for the longest time I avoided the show thinking it was some sort of cheesy game show like Survivor but with manufactured drama. It has elements of each but it is so much more with the psychological angle addressing human nature and the inherent desperation, greed, integrity and courage that every person has to some degree. I binged all 3 seasons and was impressed with all 3 although 2 and 3 are really just one season. But, episode 6 in season 1 had me in tears with a few different scenes. I rarely get choked up but the 3 scenes got to me and one in particular is still on my mind and I'm not sure I'll be able to let it go (the 2 female competitors). Anyway, I thought it was creative and clever even when extremely cruel. One of the best programs I've ever watched.

Very compelling opening episodes, but when the actual plot unravels it makes you go, "Oh, that's just it? That's kinda lame". Great acting still, amazing sets, overrides the glaring flaws of the series, an enjoyable watch overall. 7/10.

I originally gave Squid Game a solid 9/10. The first season was gripping, original, and emotionally powerful - a truly groundbreaking piece of television that deserved all the praise it received.  Unfortunately, the final season (or the most recent one) was a huge letdown. It lacked the tension, depth, and tight storytelling that made Season 1 so remarkable. Characters felt less compelling, the plot dragged in places, and it seemed more focused on spectacle than substance.  Because of that disappointing turn, I've lowered my score to a 7. I still deeply respect the first season and believe it's worth watching, but the follow-up left a sour taste that's hard to ignore.

Korean Hunger Games with better acting and much more relatable themes. The plot allegory focuses on the rampant exploitation of poor and desperate people, with the initial invitation to play the game and everything that follows appealing to their need to clear debts. This soon becomes about something much bigger and darker. Not for the squeamish.  No spoilers, but I will say I'm a vehement anti-binger when it comes to my viewing habits. In the 10-odd hour runtime of this series, though, I stopped only to sleep and make a chicken wrap.

I really enjoyed Squid Game Season 1 - the concept was fresh, intense, and emotionally gripping. The characters were well-developed, and the story kept me hooked till the end.  However, Season 2 has been a major disappointment so far. The writing feels lazy, with recycled ideas and poorly thought-out plotlines. For example, in the second game, giving every team just 5 minutes to complete all five games made absolutely no sense - it felt completely illogical and forced. The scripted voting sequences also lacked depth and felt unnatural.  After watching a few episodes, I genuinely asked myself if I should even continue watching. It's frustrating to see such a promising show fall into the trap of weak, repetitive scripting. Hoping it improves, but Season 2 so far lacks the sharpness and impact that made Season 1 so memorable.

Season 1 was a solid 8/10. It has lots of suspense, even with the cheesy vip characters acting and the easy-to-see plot twists.  Season 2 however is a nightmare. It really feels sloppily put together in typical netflix fashion. Would it really be a korean game of life and death without a token trans character learning about their body? How silly could you have made that side plot? They even had to throw in the trans-woman going to the female restroom scene, just to make a point. Absolute insanity. It was interesting to see some of the twists, but overall the side drama ruined it. It felt more like a persuasive essay on forced morality than a show about greed and death.

This series is so overrated. But let's be fair, it's a very good series. I've watched a few movies about it. The script was good. Acting was sometimes exaggerated, maybe it's a cultural thing. I did not like the final part. Overall very well done. In the final episode, my expectation was different. But the final scene was disappointing. Season 2 will come, I hope it doesn't fall into "La Casa De Papel" status.

What's up with all the series this 2024? Why are they all so fond of cliffhangers? I can't believe we waited years just to have that...  Like, the second season of the show really did a good job in continuing the fun, emotional, and intense feelings from the previous one; the performances are also outstanding, including the concepts, chemistry, production, and all, but the remaining scenes just didn't do it for me, like what happened?  I know it's a tease for what's to come, but it's also not a great one to be, like, that's it, really? I guess folks need to wait again for a long time, so yeah, there's that.

Squid game has set an extremely high bar for other shows of this genre. It is intense. It is raw. It is an emotional roller coaster. This is a masterpiece throughout. I actually felt that the poor VIP acting was a good metaphor of modern Hollywood when compared to the incredible performances by some of the main cast members here. I sincerely hope they continue the series in the same style and it does not get the SAW franchise treatment.  But Episode 6 - Gganbu.... So powerful. Possibly the best single episode of a show I have ever seen.  More, more, more please.
Great plot, great acting, and all around great show. One of the best series I've seen on netflix in a very long time. Korean cinema is absolutely the best with their story telling. 10/10!!

I would give the original series 8 to 8.5. If you don't know, the way Korean TV works is that you do one limited series and then you move onto the next project. It could be eight episodes, it could be 12 but it doesn't really run much longer than that. Therefore, when the Korean makers of the original series submitted it Netflix knew they had something interesting but they didn't know they had a cultural phenomenon. Once it blew up, the demand was for more which is not what the makers had in mind.  Series 2 and three are actually one long series. The first series was around one single tournament of the titular games. This time you get one tournament split over two seasons. Leading to a lot of filler.  The original series is high concept but to keep things going ridiculous plots vie for position with ludicrous plot twists and illogical actions. All TV and movies are artificial and designed to provoke an emotional response. But bad TV shows are where you can hear the writing and you can tell that the only reason why a character is acting against their own interests is because the writer needs to get them to a certain position. This happens way too often particularly in season three.  Season two is the bridge season and I gave it a pass because I wanted to see where it was going. However, once you're into season three you realise the writers didn't quite know how to stick the landing. There's lots going on, but sometimes it seems like it's drama for drama's sake. So as you sit there frustratedly watching the final few scenes, you realise this should've been one and done and it would've been remembered as one of the great Korean exports.  Season 1- 8.5 Season 2- 7 Season 3- 5.

Season 1 was near perfection. The plot was fresh, shockingly good and hit the emotional tone just right. Often times it felt too realistic and the acting was on point as well. And the games were well executed. They should have ended the series there. Rating: 9/10.  Season 2 only exists because season 1 was a massive hit and Netflix wanted more. The plot this time around was weaker than before. The shock value has gone and the emotional notes did not quite hit the same. Some new characters were genuinely good. Overall a good season nevertheless. Rating: 8/10.  Season 3 was basically season 2 second part. They just stretched a weaker story so much it loses the charm. One sub-plot (detective island hunt) felt exciting in the beginning but went nowhere. The other sub-plot (rogue soldier) was unnecessary and I did not like it. The drama within the players was not as exciting as season 1. And was predictable at times. Once again, brilliant acting carried the series, except the VIPs. They were hilariously bad. The new games and voting system did not have the same weight as before. Tho, these did add some drama. Finally, regarding the ending, I have mixed feeling about it. Rating: 7/10.

Disappointing. Really, really disappointing. Season 2 doesn't even come close to the brilliance of Season 1.  And the most absurd part? The main character falling for the exact same trick his "best friend" pulled on him three years ago. Like, seriously? That's Horror Movie Mistakes 101.  It feels like they took a regular season and stretched it like a piece of gum to make it last for two seasons. And even then, this feels like the first half of a 14-episode series that they'll finish next year. Honestly, they should've just condensed the whole thing into 7 solid episodes and called it a day.  The games? They're fine. Not amazing, not terrible-just "meh." Half the "special guest appearances" are so obscure, you'd only recognize them if you're a hardcore Korean drama fan who goes, "Oh my god, it's Park Sun-Hoon in a cameo! Epic!" Yeah, not me  The story is basically copy-pasted from Season 1 with nothing new to offer.  It's cute in some moments but incredibly disappointing overall. A generous 6/10 from me.  Mainly for season 1 Watch it if you must, but don't expect much except some recycled drama and half-baked games.

They should have cut at least half of it. It drags on and on. After the incredible momentum the second season built, this is a letdown. The worst thing about it are the actors playing the rich people. They look like a bunch of people that stumbled into their first improv-lesson: over-acting to degree that left me with so much 2nd-hand embarrassment that I started skipping the scenes. Remember the villains laughing in Austin Powers? Now imagine that but with complete amateurs.  The rest of it feels drawn out. This could have easily been resolved with two seasons instead of three. The pacing blunts the emotional impact when some of the main characters die.  This could have been so much better...

The games ar nothing but a real life projection, "a democracy" based on rules made by capitalism, no one takes it seriously until you need money... you work with no limits and you never find happiness... try to look different into this movie and you will find the true message, true about rules in society, about democracy, and how people change themselves how money can change someone, overall great story, great idea.

I just watched whole S3, while yes i did speed it abit. While as an editor, i have to summary it, the director said "S3 is the end, there wont be a S4 - and citing a lack of ideation. While S1 was three years ago, and 22episodes in total, the story feels pretty tapped out"  But if you've watched S3Ep6, clearly there'll be S4, you'll probably catches many changed, like the edit feels altered, some shots missing and a sudden "6 months ago" time jump, and that mystery young man. Sure the episode has some reshoots and retape, and its continuable.  Its whether change a new director?? Or selling IP?? Since its a good IP, from a business perspective, there's no way such a strong IP just ends like that. Whether it's in the story or behind; in-or-outside the scenes, this is all part of the capitalist game - just like Jigsaw, Final Destination, or Scream (which is getting a Season 7 in 2026). These are a good IP to run, so it definitely will be S4.

The show has themes and ideas that convey intense meaning. It gives joy and laughter, and every character is thought out to great detail. Keeps you on the edge and wanting more. You'll laugh, you'll cry and you'll feel for character's as if you were them. Absolutely wanting and looking foward to a season 2. Brilliant.

Squid Game's first season is undeniably compelling, though far from a masterpiece. Its gripping premise, engaging challenges, and intriguing characters promise a vast well of potential. Unfortunately, the second season drags down the series, feeling forced and short on fresh ideas-seemingly a Netflix cash grab with a heavy-handed agenda. The director himself hinted at the show's natural conclusion after Season One, but the sequel charges ahead regardless.  While the initial episodes of Season Two show some promise, everything beyond episode three becomes predictable and dull. The new characters stray too far from the solid casting of the first installment, often feeling annoying and stereotypical. Conversations grow tedious, and the tension that once made the show exhilarating fades quickly. Though there are a few decent moments scattered throughout, the overall result is mediocre at best. In sum, Season One stands out as a must-watch, whereas Season Two falls disappointingly short of its predecessor's impact.

This is honestly the best series i have ever watched i finished it in one night and now i cant stop thinking about it everything about it is perfect the storyline the events are not exepcted a lot of plot twists i have every single emotion watching this stress anxiety anger happy and i mean it i will never regret watching it good job.

Creator and director Dong-hyuk Hwang certainly had one crazy vision, and successfully made a series of it. Sure it has plot and technical issues, and I wasn't fond of the ending - I re-wrote it in my head much better, but for a somewhat newb Korean filmmaker, this was epic.  The visuals, props and sets were outstanding. The cinematography and score amazing. The casting and performances by all, except the VIP's, was excellent. Props to Neflix once again, and thanks for dubbing this one right this time. Hoping for a S2 real soon. A well deserved 8/10 from me.

Squid Game (2021-2025) is one of those shows that people have been raving about for years and it took me forever to watch because of my busy schedule, but I did finally watch both seasons of the show at the end of last year and I really enjoyed this show. Now that I have watched Season 3, I can say that this show is truly one of a kind.  Positives for Squid Game (2021-2025): The premise of this show is the thing that had me intrigue and it is one of those shows that caught my attention and it delivered on all of my expectations. This is a show that is so bleak with its tone and approach that you need someone who can understand how to execute it properly and Hwang Dong-hyuk is the person. He understood what needed to be done with this show and how to make it work for modern day audiences while also giving it an edge to make it stand out from a lot of other shows. The cast is phenomenal here with Lee Jung-jae, Lee Byung-hun, Wi Ha-joon, Park Hae-soo, Jung Ho-yeon, Im Si-wan, Jo Yu-ri and Park Sung-hoon as they plays these people who feel so real that you want to see them get out of this insane game alive and it is sad when you see these people meet their fates in the most terrible ways possible. The games we see in this show are the kind of games you would see children play except they are taken to the extreme with the high stakes and sheer brutality with how these players are being eliminated and it is so chilling with the gory. The people behind the concept of these games are your typical cartoon villains, but they are entertaining with their personalities that I came to enjoy them for their insanity. This show does a great job at executing the story in these three seasons that I can't help but applaud the creator for his work. And finally, the ending of this show is one of the best in television history, but it is also one of those finales that will divide audiences with the things that happen and I can understand their reasons for hating, but I loved it.  Overall, Squid Game (2021-2025) is a once in a generation show that need to be watched by everyone for the experience itself and it is one of the best shows during the modern era of television and I am happy to have taken part in this experience with everyone.
I really enjoy every second of this TV show it's so perfect and amazing it deserves 10 out of 10.
Compelling, iam have way thru didn't got boring once so far. Nice designs, graphics and characters. Worth the watch for sure.

Well, Squid Game would have been a 10 out of 10 if it had ended after the first season, and it definitely should have. But since the whole series has to be considered, there's a massive point deduction because seasons 2 and 3 were both an absolute disaster. As a result, the show doesn't even qualify as 'pretty good' anymore; it's just 'meh' at best.  Seasons 2 and 3 added absolutely nothing, and I mean really nothing, to the series. Not a single new or original idea. None of the many questions were answered. Nothing the audience had hoped for actually happened. The series basically ends just as abruptly as it did after season 2. And before anyone says, 'The show probably isn't over yet' - it is. It was one of the worst follow-ups to a series ever, which is insane considering how reliably strong Korean dramas usually are and how incredibly solid the foundation was that season 1 built.  Really a shame. I can probably count on one hand the number of shows that would have been better if they had ended after season one. I don't understand why they even continued the series if they clearly had no ideas left.

Same category as Breaking Bad, very very very good. Movies like this arent made that often. It's got to be your kind of.movie, I'm sure not everyone's cup of tea, but if you watch at least 3 episodes you will finish it. Especially created a IMDB account to rate this series. Says enough I think. Go watch it!

H Review:  For me, Squid Game was an intense and shocking experience. The deadly game isn't just about survival-it explores greed, desire, hope, and moral choices of human beings. The characters are realistic and multi-dimensional, showing how people behave under extreme circumstances. The games, cleverly and frighteningly designed, create a constant sense of anxiety, drawing the viewer deep into the story. The music, color palette, and atmosphere make the series a unique and captivating experience. Squid Game symbolizes struggle, humanity, and unforgettable thrilling television memories for me.

Forgive me for the title, i could not come up with anything more creative, that's on me. This is a serious review, let me be clear.  Squid game is such a thoughtful and detailed show, it's hard to know where to begin discussing it. The writing is done with passion, the characters are created with love, and every set and costume is built with deep intention.  The premise is pretty simple. Struggling people compete for money. The show's brilliance lies beyond its premise though.  The show itself is a commentary on the ultra wealthy 1% and how they treat people who aren't as successful as they are. They treat the poorer like how kings treat jesters, laughing in the face of their financial struggles. The message isn't meant to be direct, it's meant to be hidden beneath layers of metaphor and subtext- something i've seen a lot of reviewers here not pick up on.  But commenting on capitalism isn't all the show has to offer, it also has themes about interpersonal connection and trust. Do we trust those who are accomplished on their own, or do we trust those who can accomplish great things with others? How much money is enough to be willing to die for? Who would you be wiling to hurt in order to elevate your own life? Director hwang dong-hyuk did such an amazing job exploring questions like these.  No characters feel like copies of each other, they're all different enough from each other to make a good story without being unrealistic. Our main character, seong gi-hun, is really admirable. He's kind, thoughtful, and dedicated to others, no matter the circumstance. He's shown to be empathetic, even when faced with the possibility of death, which is just such a power move.  Yes, it's bloody, and yes, it can be over the top with the murder factor, but if you look beneath the gore, you'll see a genuine show, created with unbelievable levels of effort and passion. I'm truthful when i say i don't think there are any bad episodes of squid game.  I've seen some reviews saying this show glorifies death, but that can't be further from the truth. Squid game shows a lot of people die, a lot of very different people, to show that no matter what you do, no matter who you are, no matter how hard you try in life, you're damned. The show wants you to feel bad when desperate people in need of money force themself into such an awful situation that they're willing to die and kill for cash.  And only 3 seasons, thank goodness. I am so glad that netflix didn't demand more expansion like they did with stranger things.  As my closing statement, i'll say this: i know this show is good because it made my mother cry, and that woman is strong as steel.

The first couple of episodes a very well done and pack a punch, but by the end it just seems to run out of steam. The marbles episode was the last real swerve, after that it becomes paint by numbers to the point that I started fast forwarding through most of it just to get it to end.  Early episodes are an eight, final episodes are a three.

And because that rhymed I'll keep it going that way and to reiterate, I gotta say The episodes in the middle of the show are probably the strongest I ever saw of any tv series - forgein or domestic.  But in general - this show was majestic.  Character development is really great I cared for them quickly instead of late.  And to make them easier to differentiate, they even gave them numbers like 2-1-8.  The last 2 episodes fell off a little bit, but they're still good - not saying they're ... I think this production is the best to ever come out of Asia where the acting's usually dumb and over the top.  Here some of Asia's finest acting is displayed I really like how their characters are portrayed.  I'm late to the party, after the hype has died but let me close saying the hype was justified.

The creator of the show had confirmed that season 3 is the last season of the show.  I completed the whole show and it was brilliant but the story of the show hadn't completed and leave a lot of questions like: Q: who created the games?  Q: what is the philosophy of the games?  Q: who's the VIPs? Did they created games?  Q: what the front man(captain) did? Did he betrayed the masters? Is he regret what he did?  Besides this the show is full of emotions and trauma. It portrayed very beautifully the nature of humans.  Although it is one the best Korean netflix show.  The final scene suggests that the game isn't over, just shifted to another location, probably US.

Personally Squid Game became one of my favorite TV shows back in 2021, but season 2 didn't make the pass. They repeated almost the exact same formula and characters apart of some very few things they added. You can't connect with most of the new characters since most of them have very little screentime or are killed off almost immediately, plus most of them are written off to be complete jerks or unlikable. It's disappointing that a series spend 3 years in production and they give us this, yet is even more ridiculous they want us to await for almost one whole year more to release the spare episodes, like ¿are you kidding me? ¿really Netflix? Season 1 is 8/10, season 2 a 3/10.

Extremely great and innovative. This film is frighteningly real and all of the performances of the actors are stellar and force you to not only be glued to the screen but to also carry the weight and feelings and emotions of the show with you for a little or sometimes long while after the episode has finished. Not sure if this was initially released weekly but I cannot even imagine the torture of that had I tried to watch it at the time it came out. It is very difficult to stop watching but also I was sometimes forced to because it became too emotional and invasive to me. Great work from director, actor's and whole crew as well as extras and extras casting. Great experience that won't leave you for a long time.

Even though there are many gameshows that require contestants to survive for one reason or another, Squid Game stands out thanks to its breathtaking visuals and superbly written characters. The former is done through colorful scenery that perfectly fits the "kids games" theme as well as the organized nature of a secretive organization's facility that houses so many people. As for the latter, EVERY character is struggling to make ends meet but how they put themselves in that position is extremely unique. The group is diverse with the main guy having to pay a debt he owes to land sharks, his friend having embezzled money from his business, an old man who is living out his remaining time with a brain tumor, a gangster who stole money from his boss, a woman who got scammed and more. Add to that the dark humor, an unraveling mystery surrounding the game show, and violence and you have the recipe for an addictively bingeable show.

I genuinely enjoyed this show from beginning to end. A true social commentary on humanity, competition and avarice. When the carnage is occurring it's nail-biting and between the games you get compelling human drama - a fantastic addition to the "kill game" genre that seems to always be elevated by Korean talent behind and in front of the camera.  Updated: Season 3 is disappointing. The story feels aimless, and none of the characters are likable or even sympathetic. The emotional weight from earlier seasons is gone. The ending was especially bad, like a rushed setup for some kind of American spin-off. And honestly, the scariest part wasn't the games... it was the VIPs speaking English like it was their first time using the language. This season had potential, but it felt more like a cash grab than a meaningful continuation.

It's true. The more the sequels, the lesser the quality of the sequel. Season 1 was fire, got us so hooked. Season 2, good. But season 3, nope. They got lazy ( 1 less episode than season 2). In a rush of finishing the series, they didn't even bother with ethics nor the fact that 456's intent was to defy and destroy the criminal organization. Maybe they had a deadline, or they were running out of budget. They eliminated a lot of the interesting people on the show. Maybe those people were big actors/actresses thus the elimination. Well, that's squid game for you. But that finale though, very lazy , some creativity would have been nice. It looked as though they just mashed everything up so that the finale is long.

I LOVED this show, you can binge-watch it, it's addictive.  I don't like horror and blood, but this one was more of a thriller-suspense, even I liked it.  It's a mix of: the chess scene from the first Harry Potter, Black Mirror and The platform.  It's very hard to guess what's coming next, it keeps you interested and guessing.

Season 1 of Squid Game was a masterclass in storytelling - raw, original, and emotionally powerful. Unfortunately, what followed is a textbook example of what happens when profit overshadows purpose.  Season 2 abandons the narrative integrity that made the first season resonate, offering instead a disjointed and uninspired continuation. Season 3 goes even further - a grotesque distortion of the original vision, pandering to shock value rather than substance.  What could have ended as a cultural landmark is now diluted by the very greed the show once criticized. Sometimes, "more" is simply too much.

Squid Game is a fascinating and visually stunning series that left me thoroughly impressed. The show's unique premise, coupled with its masterful execution, made it an unforgettable experience.  One of the standout elements is its visual appeal-vibrant, surreal settings juxtaposed against the grim reality of life-and-death stakes. The games themselves were meticulously designed to evoke genuine tension and unpredictability, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats. The high stakes, where failure meant death, added an unparalleled intensity to every scene.  On a psychological level, Squid Game delves into the darkest corners of human nature. It explores themes of greed and ambition, showcasing how far individuals are willing to go-even at the expense of others' lives-for a chance at wealth. Another compelling theme is the moral dilemmas faced when survival becomes personal; the series starkly illustrates how self-preservation can lead one to betray even their closest allies.  However, while the series excels in many areas, the ending left much to be desired. The conclusion felt open-ended and unresolved, leaving several critical questions unanswered. It's clear the story has more to offer, and I can only hope that the next season will address these lingering threads.  Overall, Squid Game is a phenomenal series that masterfully combines suspense, social commentary, and visual artistry. I thoroughly enjoyed it and eagerly anticipate what comes next!

Overall i'd say this show deserves an 8.5 for season 1.  It seems like they made season 2 with a lot of greed. They made 10 episodes. They then made filler story for 4 extra episodes (14 total) and split it into 2 seasons.  This is the same thing that ruined the Hobbit and the Hunger Games. Those movies are still fine, but so much potential was wasted just to make some extra money. If those movies had 1 less movie, they'd be so much better.  We now have 2 shorter seasons of 7 episodes with a lot of filler moments. It's a shame because season 1 was very packed with a good story. Now it drags on a lot of times in season 2. Not to mention that the story cuts of literally in the middle of the story.  It was very obviously forced into 2 seasons just so Netflix could ride the succes of the show for longer. It really is a shame. I wish we could just tell a good story and end it on a high note. Milking popular shows dry is a shame. It ruins any rewatch potential in the future.

As another review says, the VIPs acting is not bad. The only reason native English speakers find it bad is because they speak very slowly and clear, as the show is not intended for English speakers.  I usually check reviews on FilmAffinity, (the Spanish version) and literally no one there was talking about how bad the VIPs were. So, for Spanish speakers, the acting doesn't seem bad. It is as simple as that.  As for the show, it is a great show. I strongly recommend watching it.  Maybe not a 10/10 as that is reserved for films that changed my life, but definitely a 8/10.  It is a great metaphor of capitalism and how our society forces people into extreme situations.

A series or movie that makes time pass quickly because you're so into it is greatly appreciated by me. So many titles to choose from but only a few leave you with a feeling of satisfaction after viewing. Several Korean series hit that mark, Vagabond, Kingdom, Tunnel, to name a few. The only problem I have is with scenes that go on way to long, Nine episodes could've been cut to six with some efficient editing but other than that I loved it.

A great concept here as desperate people with financial problems compete for a huge sum of money(apparently $38 mil American). They must play games against one another with a severe penalty for losing. Like the Sopranos, with some of the episodes better than others. Number six was the best for me. The sets are Wes Anderson like, with bright colors filling the screen. The lead actors are excellent and the scripts very well written. The violence is over the top with no comic relief in sight. The final episode was a bit of a letdown but overall I was highly entertained.
This show was amazing, apart from the thrill, drama and violence, it tried to show the social inequalities that people have to live with and they fight to survive! Yet another Korean masterpiece.

While I do give Squid Game credit for it's inivative and interesting premise, the film has an underlying issue of direction and overall moral message. The problem occurs more frequently in season 2 when the main cast struggles to find a singular goal or overall personality. The acting has greatly declined in season 2. The director said that there was no plans of a season 2 while they filmed season 1 and it is pretty obvious as each episode consists of patternistic fighting, consuling, and retribution. The overall goal of season 2 is revenge on the man but it takes multiple detours and becomes a disshovled soap opera. The strengths come late for season 2 as the final 2 episodes hold the most impact while not as much as season 1 does it still gives you a reward for sitting through its runtime. One recommendation is that you should watch it with only subtitles and not dubbed over.

Simply immersive. Thats my general consensus. I am only up to episode 4?(i am binging it so lost track) but this is almost meditative - the scope of this. The filmaking is on another level. Its so revolutionary, everything in it. Dont want to spoil it. Must watch..  the acting is just superb and it will keep you guessing.  The genre not to spoil is mystery/dystopia.

The series starts strong and gradually declines. The first season is quite good - it presents a very interesting new concept. I believe that's what created the initial impact and gave it its popularity.  The acting is honestly weak, if not outright bad, but as I mentioned, the novelty factor manages to keep the viewer entertained.  The following seasons continue with the poor performances and lose the freshness of the original idea. I think that's why the show starts to feel like it's going downhill. The novelty wears off, the plot isn't particularly engaging beyond the world it introduces, and it ends up exhausting the viewer.  In fact, some of the situations in the later seasons feel so forced they come off as downright bizarre. I didn't like the ending.

I went into Season 3 hoping for a return to what made the series awesome. Unfortunately, this season fell completely flat for me. First of all the acting of the VIPS was so bad forced and overly dramatic, also they just simply could not act, they did not seem like rich people or better said vips.  The plot was even more confusing character motivations were all over the place, and major twists seemed thrown in just for shock value rather than story logic. Since they changed characters like 388 COMPLETELY, I kept waiting for a deeper message or narrative thread to tie it all together, but it never came. Compared to the suspenseful writing of Season 1, this felt messy and rushed. Honestly, unless you're watching just to finish the series, I really wouldn't recommend it.

Nihilistic. Depraved. Pointless.  Squid Game pretends to be a critique of capitalism, but it's a lie-an empty shell wrapped in stylized gore and cheap moral theater. There's no compass here. No resistance. No guide through the nightmare. Just suffering, stacked on more suffering, offered up for consumption like bread and circuses in a neon hell.  Unlike Dante's descent in The Inferno, there's no Virgil, no redemption, no reckoning-just a rigged system and characters who either die or comply. No one rises. No one fights back. The game isn't a metaphor. It's a meat grinder.  Compared to Silence of the Lambs, this thing lacks any psychological depth or truth. Clarice chased justice. These people just get herded toward slaughter, framed as spectacle. It's not commentary. It's cruelty dressed up as significance.  A soulless diatribe of falsehoods wrapped in violence, screaming into the wind, signifying nothing.  I turned it off. I won't be back. And I won't pretend there's meaning in the mess.

"Squid Game" had all the ingredients to become an iconic series, but it falters in its execution due to predictable storytelling, lazy writing, and inconsistent logic. While the premise is intriguing-a deadly game where players compete for survival-the show struggles to maintain its momentum and emotional weight.  One of the major flaws is its predictability. Key plot twists and character arcs can be spotted a mile away, making the tension and suspense feel hollow. Instead of keeping the audience on edge, the series often telegraphs its moves, reducing the impact of pivotal moments.  The writing, unfortunately, leans on convenience rather than depth. There are numerous contradictions in the story, particularly around the rules of the games. For example, players are explicitly told they cannot influence voting, yet the show repeatedly bends these rules for the sake of lazy dialogue or manufactured drama. This lack of consistency undermines the believability of the narrative and pulls viewers out of the experience.  Conversations in the series often drag on unnecessarily. Instead of building tension or deepening character relationships, they feel like filler. Dialogue is repetitive and lacks the sharpness needed to elevate the characters or the story. As a result, emotional moments that should hit hard fall flat, leaving little lasting impact.  While the show occasionally delivers moments of visual intrigue and social commentary, the lack of emotional depth and clumsy pacing makes it feel like a missed opportunity. "Squid Game" is entertaining in parts, but it fails to live up to the potential of its concept, leaving viewers with a series that is more frustrating than satisfying.
Loved every minute, couldn't stop watching!  They did a great job in making it feel more "realistic" and not like SAW or some other classic horror/thriller movie.
Gi-Hun is played by Lee Jung-Jae not my Greg Chun.  Kindly edit the cast.

This is a series from South Korea in mainly the Korean language I am 99% sure the reason why the VIPs are talking the way they are is because of this They are not acting bad, the acting is fine! What feels amiss to us is that they talk slowly and pronounce very clearly, and this is deliberate. They speak slowly and clearly because this show was intended for a Korean audience and not an US or even English speaking audience and this is why it feels kinda off to those people We are used to Netflix shows in US or British English where people speak perfect everyday English (whatever that means) and here they tried to ensure a non English speaker or someone with limited English skills can follow the VIP conversations This is my theory I said what I said Love this series and it's the best thing that's come off Netflix in a while so think for a minute and stop hating on this detail in an otherwise AWESOME show!
Squid games is amazing! From the first episode to the last, the tv series had my attention! Can't wait for season 2.  Explores human psychology really well!

To be honest the hype is way overrated. It's good on the first season but the season 2 and season 3 is clearly dragged. Season 2 and 3 is not well written. They fail to make the story become deeper and the other characters seriously become useless like the police finding the island all season long. There's only one noticeable character here aside from the main lead. The rest is really uselss The protagonists is the generic type of protagonists that all they do is blabbering  If you watch alot of korean movie, they like to make the characters talk a lot. They even talk to themselves.  They should focus instead in the games as it is the highlights of the movie.

If you're on the fence, definitely give the show a try. I wasn't sure what to expect, but it's definitely in my "all-time favorites" now.  It was a really good show until one of the episodes, which elevated the show to the next level and cemented its place on my all-time favorites list. I would have given the series a 10, but I was disappointed with the ending, which is why I lowered the score to a 9.  Despite the ending, I consider it a must watch, or at the very least, a must try.

Squid Game Season 3 is a complete disappointment. The main character, after all the emotional buildup from previous seasons, returns only to do absolutely nothing. His presence is irrelevant and he ends up being just another spectator, with no real impact on the story. Why did he even come back? The guy on the boat, another character who seemed important, also adds nothing. The entire season builds expectations that are never fulfilled. The pacing is slow, the new characters fail to connect, and the ending is terrible: no consequences, no surprises, no soul. All the potential was wasted in a script with no direction or purpose. A true betrayal to the fan, is horrible.

When I first saw season 1 after it came out, I already loved the show and it's vibe, until the internet kinda ruined Squid Game's image. Now most just think of the silly life or death games when they hear Squid Game, but I feel like people are missing out on the show. (I might be wrong, I just don't know anyone that genuinely enjoyed the show)  Season 1 starts off strong. Likeable characters, thrilling sequences, great overall vibe and pacing,.. It's the reason it got so popular anyways. Some might find season 1 a bit less to their liking, which I get. The beginning and ending are a bit slowly paced, and sometimes the show itself got a little unhinged. Apart from that, season 1 is great when it comes to setting up the ending and the start of season 2.  Season 2 starts off, again, slowly paced, but for a good reason. It sets the tone and the actions of our characters well. Some might not like the slow pace, which I get, (because we don't get to the games instantly) but they did very well for me.  When the games begin, the show got its season 1 vibe again. The new games, the (once again) great new characters, the emotion, the thrills,... I personally loved it through the whole thing. Apart from still having the season 1 vibe, it had its own "charm". The tone was different, which I think some might not like. For example, the setting isn't only the games itself, but also outside of that (sometimes) and the rules of the games changed a bit, but I think that opened up great new opportunities, and it delivered.  The ending was thrilling, but it missed that thrill that the games usually had. It had less impact on me than I thought. Still great to kick off season 3, I hope.  If you liked season 1, you will like season 2. If you think Squid Game is a silly show which just had impact on youtube shorts and brainrot content, reconsider.

Excellent show with incredible attention to detail on the psychology of different characters and how the relationships between these characters develop during the game. Definitely worth the binge in one night! The show is incredible in terms of scriptwriting AND acting and has an exciting unpredictability to it. Additionally, the soundtrack was brilliantly consistent and the repetitiveness helped tie all the episodes together.  The only element in this show which was slightly worse was the acting of the VIP's from episode 7 and onward. They weren't too bad, but their acting was noticeably worse than the Korean actors.

After a three-year wait, Squid Game Season 2 finally arrived but unfortunately it left me underwhelmed. If I had to sum up my experience in one word, it would be really "DISAPPOINTMENT." The first season was a masterclass in simplicity, suspense and emotional resonance which contributed to its massive popularity. Naturally, my expectations for Season 2 were sky-high. Sadly, the new installment lacked the very elements that made its predecessor so compelling. The creator's vision for Season 2 seemed unclear and the show meandered losing focus. The initial episodes were slow-paced with excessive conversations that could have been condensed. The character development while detailed felt unnecessary and overshadowed the main plot.  The new characters introduced in Season 2 failed to resonate emotionally, leaving me feeling detached. The games which were supposed to be the highlight were poorly executed and lacked the emotional impact I had anticipated. It seemed like the show's creators were more concerned with showcasing their elaborate set designs and structured plot rather than delivering meaningful content. The result was a lackluster experience that culminated in a violent and unsatisfying conclusion.  On a positive note, the music and cinematography were impressive but these aspects alone couldn't redeem the season's shortcomings.  Overall, Squid Game Season 2 was a disappointment, failing to recapture the magic of its predecessor. Hoping that the creators will refocus for future installments.  Rating for season 2 --->> 3/10.
Often tough to watch but a gripping series if you can see it out.

I'm writing this review after seeing the second season of this show. I have to say that I do not agree with the growing opinion that the second season was a huge letdown and did not live up to the original. While I do think the first season told a more complete story with better pacing, I still believe with season 2 we are looking at an incomplete story, that should wait for the final one in order to be judged fairly.  The split, probably a Netflix ruling to retain subscriptions, was not perfectly placed, but I will refrain from holding it against the show, because so much of what it does holds true and retains the spirit of the first season.  Gi-Hun is back, and is after the managers of the game to put it to an end. The idea to put him back in the game is a contentious decision, but I do think that if he were to be left out, and we followed him solely trying to track down the game masters, without his presence among the players, the storyline of the games would have been less interesting, and would definitely have been a retread of the original.  As it is, it's interesting to have a former victor in the Games (there's a reason Catching Fire is the best Hunger Games book and movie). But the perk of having a victor inside the arena goes out quickly because the games change. Again, of course the games have to change, but it means that Gi-Hun loses his edge in a way that regresses his character.  They don't do a lot with him besides having him urge other players to stop playing and vote out after each game and take the money earned so far. Those two elements are the key fresh ideas that make the games feel new and not wholly Do-overs. It's a great idea to explore the gamble aspect of playing "one more game", because it goes deep into the Hot-Hand fallacy mentality of a degenerate gambler, which is what a lot of the players are, and one of the ways through which the game masters control them.  But it does mean that Gi-Hun has to leverage compelling points to urge them to stop, and the writers don't have him make great arguments, it's just a bit repetitive dialogue, but that also might be the result of poor subtitles. His dialogue might be more insightful when understood in the original Korean.  The other characters are great, they provide interesting archetypes that explore new angles of the downtrodden, that the first game didn't. Instead of husband and wife we have a mother and son, a pregnant girl, a trans woman, ex-militaries, online sensations, with even some interesting commentaries on social media finance gurus, which all work great.  Again, this is the best part of Squid Game, it's not the games themselves, it's what the Games have to reveal about these different people, how they portray themselves in the games, out of them, what makes them want to play and what makes them stop, and I think season 2 does this like season 1 did, it just does it in a manner that's incomplete.  There's a lot left to explore for every character in the show for Season 3. I will admit that there are structural issues because the storyline with the cop is pretty left to the wayside, the female guard we follow on the inside is also left hanging, and the subplot with the guards trafficking organs is also a bit half-baked, but I have faith in what they have in store, and to speak of what we have so far, I'm liking it.  Everyone in season 1 complained about the VIP's and there has been nothing nearly as bad as that in season 2, the VIP's haven't even showed up (though I think they should in season 3, just better done).  Finally, one key twist that is revealed early in season 2 is pretty interesting, intelligent and compelling. At first glance it might seem like a repeat of season 1 as well, but once you contemplate the ways in which it's different from season 1, it will be clear that it's a great move, that changes things dramatically, and that honestly, saves the season in my eyes.

Was Season 3 worth the wait? Honestly, not really. It started with promise but quickly drifted into what felt like a drawn-out filler arc. The tension, the stakes, the clever writing that made previous seasons shine - it all took a back seat. Instead, we got a season full of empty build-up with barely any real payoff. By the time the finale came around, it was clear that the whole purpose was just to set up a new direction rather than give closure. And while setting up the future isn't always a bad thing, doing it at the cost of an entire season? That's a problem. They had the potential to dig deeper with smarter scenarios and tighter storytelling, but instead, it felt lazy - like they knew they'd already hooked us and didn't feel the need to try. A frustrating waste of momentum.
I m falling shortage of words. All i can say is it is 100/100 and a must watch for all thriller show lovers. All episodes are worth watching.

One of the well-made, and original shows. The highlights: its writing, creative direction, Large and beautiful set design, character developments, and an uncovering of the truth of Humanity. Though it is not for faint-hearted people as it is brutal and disturbing in many ways still A masterpiece that every movie premyy should watch. Highly Recommended! ❤
One of the best shows I've ever watched, I hate the VIPs though.
Very well made series. They have done an exceptional job here with Netflix money. Definitely recommend.

Korean Drama "Squid Game" is bloody, but, somehow, hopeful.  It has a nice cinematography, with, sometimes, overused gore, but well executed action scenes. The background stories, moreover, set the drama apart from the rest of the survival game series, and it gives a more 'Korean Drama' feel to it. It makes the story more believable, as it helps the viewer relate to the characters and understand them. It also gave a more humane twist to the story and made it more dramatic, when the settings and the costumes were more on the childish side.  Finally, the performances were great by everyone in the cast.  So, overall, 7 out of 10.
The series is so good and so emotional it is itself the first series i watched in korean. Highly recommended!

So.... the ENTIRE premise is based on 'let's play games that we played as kids, that were based on skill and that are completely fair, and we're ALL on equal ground'.... series keeps that premise from EP01 until EP05, where it becomes not only a rigged game, but also no longer based on skill, but COMPLETELY based on luck. This is a GIANT problem because the entire premise of "we play fair games against each other, based on skill" is throw out the window. Honestly, the series is pretty great before that, but after that, the series is a poor 5/10. If they didn't completely throw out the premise that the series was based on, half way down the line, then this would have been a 9/10 series. I think they should make a Season2, and I just hope to God that in Season2, they don't completely derail the premise like they did in Season1, because Season1 is completely spoiled because of that.

The concept is pretty good-how far would you go to win a life changing amount of money, especially when you have hit your lowest point? I think a good 2 hour movie would have worked just as well; start by cutting out the entire "VIP" nonsense. Everything else was so well scripted and designed, how did that part fail so badly? Also, I skipped the entire first 40 minutes of the first episode and lost none of the story. That tells me it was just a time filler. My only other real issue is the captions, which are pretty awful. This appears overall to be a high value production, great costumes, sets, cinematography, why skimp on something as necessary as captioning?

Season 1 was a great show that received a 10/10 rating from me. Although it felt a bit unusual at times (coming from someone who had no previous experience with Korean shows whatsoever), the plot was good, the character development was great, and the moral of the story was all well thought out. Scenery, lighting, acting - everything looked well, and the reason for me giving it a perfect score was the, back then, innovative story and the new ideas.  Now, after having watched season 2, I have to reduce my overall rating to 5/10, as season 2 feels exactly like what it is: Enforced. They had to come up with this sequel because Netflix wanted a sequel, not because they had more story to tell, or more ideas to put on screen.  Season 3 will be happily skipped.

One of the best shows I have seen in a long time. Highly recommend watching it if you don't mind watching in Korean. The English dub isn't as good as the Korean version so I recommend you watch with English subtitles. Brilliant acting throughout.
So good I can't even describe it , story acting everything is soooooo goooood !
The best K Netflix Series I've seen recently.  Hope they will release season 2 and 3 and moreeeee!!

First and foremost, a big round of applause for the director 👏👏👏 This is by far the darkest and most 'un-korean', edgiest Korean TV series I've watched to date.  There isn't the typical sponsored usage of Samsungs, Mercedes, Subway, McDonald's or any of the big names that one would catch in a typical Korean TV series.  It's grippingly leaves you at the edge of your seat craving for the next episode and the next.  A must watch and absolutely loved the idea of the series.

I watched the series in german sync. I cannot understand the bad reviews about the VIPs. In the german sync version they speak english to underline the international connection to the "Squid game". Of course some of them are not native speakers and the fact, that they all wear masks makes it even harder to act, but keep in mind that this is a korean production and the budget was definitely litmited for these charakters.
Wow, I cannot believe this show! Ending was a bit ????? But overall excellent great work Netflix.
