No endless preaching from the hypocrites (which constantly pulls you out of the movie experience) but good 'le inventive and exciting entertainment.  This is a high quality dystopian series from our Korean friends.  If you are sick to the back teeth of modern day Hollywood sensibilities and microagressions like 95% of mankind then watch this macro aggression series. Highly recommended.
This show is absolutely amazing! You should definitely watch it.

Squid Game 2 dares to break free from the formulaic conventions of modern television storytelling, delivering a refreshingly bold narrative that challenges the status quo. While much of contemporary TV has embraced cinematic visuals but often falters in delivering substance, Squid Game 2 sets itself apart by refusing to rely on fluff. It not only revisits the complex characters fans grew attached to in the first installment but also expands their world with fresh ambition, crafting a story that feels both original and deeply rooted in the series' ethos.  The seven-episode structure is methodical and deliberate. Remarkably, the games that define the Squid Game universe don't even commence until the third episode, a decision that feels as daring as it is rewarding. By taking the time to reorient viewers to the emotional and psychological stakes of the series, the showrunners ensure that when the games finally arrive, they carry immense weight. This slower build is reminiscent of The Empire Strikes Back-a masterclass in world-building that leans on character development, tension, and cliffhanger endings to deliver a deeply immersive experience.  That said, this risk-taking approach isn't without its flaws. Episode 5, in particular, becomes an awkward stumbling block in an otherwise tight narrative. This is where we are fully introduced to a new trans character. While the inclusion of such a character is commendable on paper, the execution feels forced and arbitrary. A bathroom scene, where female characters decide to step away for seemingly no reason other than to facilitate a moment of acceptance for the trans character, feels unnecessary and breaks the narrative flow. It's a bold cultural statement, but one that adds little to the overall story.  Later in the same episode, the trans character's backstory is explored in detail. As a high-ranking soldier who was forced out of the military upon coming out as trans, they join the games with the dream of winning enough money for surgery in Thailand. While this is an intriguing setup, the handling of the character feels contrived, with their motivations and backstory introduced so late in the series that it doesn't feel fully earned. Instead of being a nuanced addition, the storyline becomes a distraction from the larger narrative.  By the time the final episode arrives, Squid Game 2 shifts into high gear, racing to tie up loose ends while setting the stage for future installments. The decision to end on a cliffhanger, much like The Empire Strikes Back, is bold but divisive, leaving many viewers with a sense of frustration. The deliberate pacing and rich storytelling of the earlier episodes make the rushed conclusion feel jarring.  Despite these missteps, Squid Game 2 succeeds in creating a gripping, original tale that captures the essence of the series while daring to take risks. Its flaws may be noticeable, but its ambition is undeniable. For fans of the original, Squid Game 2 offers a thrilling, if imperfect, return to a world that continues to captivate.
It's a 10/10. Just edit out the VIPs, you don't need them at all. Loved it. A masterpiece.

Season 1 was brilliant. The pacing was great and the writing, almost perfect. 9/10  Season 2 was watchable, but after the last episode of S2, the entire season felt pointless. Although, it raised hopes and expectations for season 3. 7.5/10  But now, after season 3, I would rate the entire series a solid 7 and S3, a 6.7.  It had its plus points, the acting, action scenes, and quite a few thrilling moments, 3-4 well written side characters but overall this season was not it. It totally didn't live up to expectations and the writer just jumped on the hype train, making it all seem pointless.  Now, onto the negative points-  1. The VIPs should have been menacing and evil but instead they looked like idiots with lots of money. Everytime they spoke, it was a cring-fest.  2. The subplot was good initially, but then it lost direction. The policeman's character added nothing to the plot. It could have been erased and the plot would remain the same.  3. The characters were dumbed down. The policeman was intelligent but in S2 and S3, he made foolish decisions and turned into a stupid person trying to play detective. The rest of the characters made questionable decisions too which got irritating at some point.  4. There were too many loopholes, and so many actions that were just there for the convenience of the plot. Season 1 was brilliant. The pacing was great and the writing, almost perfect. 9/10  Season 2 was watchable, but after the last episode of S2, the entire season felt pointless. Although, it raised hopes and expectations for season 3. 7.5/10  But now, after season 3, I would rate the entire series a solid 7 and S3, a 6.7.  It had it's plus points, the acting, action scenes, and quite a few thrilling moments, 3-4 well written side characters but overall this season was not it. It totally didn't live up to expectations and the writer just jumped on the hype train, making it all seem pointless.  Now, onto the negative points-  1. The VIPs should have been menacing and evil but instead they looked like idiots with lots of money. Everytime they spoke, it was a cring fest.  2. The subplot was good initially, but then it lost direction. The policeman's character added nothing to the plot. It could have been erased and the plot would remain the same.  3. The characters were dumbed down. The policeman was intelligent but in S2 and S3, he made foolish decisions and turned into a stupid person trying to play detective. The rest of the characters made questionable decisions too which got irritating at some point.  4. There were too many loopholes, and so many actions that were just there for the convenience of the plot. At times, it felt like a competition for who could perform the dumbest action.  5. No proper world building and the characters weren't that well written. Opposted to the attachment that we all felt for characters in S1, there was no impact of deaths in the final season.  6. Honestly, I lost touch with characters due to bad writing. Even Gi-hun felt like some random character in initial episodes of the finale. Though, the ending of his arc was satisfactory.  7. The pacing was really erratic. Some things were rushed and the others were dragged too much. Could've slept through the entire thing.  8. Sometimes, less is more. And Squid Games was one of those series which should have known where to tap out.  In short, season 3 had plenty of potential and a great concept but it was executed horribly.  The storytelling lost all sense of direction.  What started as a brilliant series spiralled into a disappointment and a directionless cash-grab, desperately being turned into a franchise.

So good to see a truly entertaining TV show for a change, enjoyed every single episode, a big round of applause for Korean entertainment. And don't worry about the bad VIPs, they're not in it for long and the masks are beautiful.

This series has everything and really captures what money does to people. It's shocking, moving and gripping all at the same time. Fantastic concept and all my grown up kids have watched it and we all loved it.

I get the premise.. I get the idea.. I just don't get the acting. You have characters acting super goofy at times and then super serious at other times.. like, not on a real world scale but a comical scale.. it's like watching Jim Carrey switch from Ace Ventura to Keanu Reeves' John Wick (in the beginning of the first one).. how are you gonna have a goofy nerd making absurd faces and dancing around like and idiot some badass later on? It makes no sense.. certainly have never witnessed this in any human behavior I've ever seen. It's like they wrote the part for 4 very different people and then combined it into one.. I give it points for originality but I hated the characters. They all could have died and it would have probably turned out better.

This k-horror is a must see. Lots of blood and death this tale is not for those with weak stomachs. But this tale delivers more than just shock value. It's a commentary on high stakes gambling where there is no risk greater than death. Children's games harken innocence while greed and sacrifice decide each players fate. The "VIP's" are the weakest link, depicted as caricatures of selfish rapacious greed; but even with their one dimensionality there is a lot of social commentary to consider.

When I first watched squid game, my standards weren't that high. However, it exceeded my standards and is up there with my top 3 favourite TV shows.  I thoroughly enjoyed the plot and the interesting concept. The games were well designed and intense to watch and SOME characters you can relate with.  I think Squid Game is probably near to as good as the Saw franchise.  If you like Saw and survival movies, you should definitely watch, you won't regret it.

Man! This show!  Does everything right at the best times. Just when you forget some detail that would make you feel brilliantly smart, it comes back to whack you in the face!  Like some of it's contemporaries it brilliantly fuses comedy and horror in the most psychological of way's and I must say, I really want more of this, and more like this.

Season one gave viewers a full story arc. Season two ended in the middle of that story arc. Absolutely zero story lines resolved. This makes the end of season 2 feel more like a mid-season cliff-hanger a la LOST than a complete season of a show. Highly disappointing.  Everything else about season 2 added and built upon season one. New characters were introduced and played poignantly and expertly by the actors. The individual character arcs were told well, and of course the games were as exciting and entertaining to watch as always.  As the tension of the season continues to build, the story seems to be building to something that will resolve a heck of a lot of tension. What viewers were given instead was a serious let down. I don't know what the reasoning was for the season ending abruptly the way it did, but I don't know if I will want to watch more if it's going to be treated this recklessly in the future. I'm reminded of the season 6 finale of The Walking Dead...
RECOMMENDED. Finished this in one night. I cant stop watching it. Worth every episodes.
Good but not as much as people talk about it.  Could be ended in lesser episodes.  For me it's a overrated series. You won't miss a lot if you don't watch it.

The symbolism behind this show is representative of The Dangerous Game and Eyes Wide Shut. Satanic billionaires that run all our world institutions bored with all they have desperate to feel any kind of emotion, which apparently comes from dehumanizing the masses and defiling the innocent.  Those that find enjoyment are already lost to degeneracy. You are subconsciously being conditioned to accept this as normal. Pay attention.  Is it a conspiracy theory if they are telling you what they are doing?
A mix of Hunger Games, Parasite, Hostel and Saw.  It shows how human nature really is.

This is definitely the most diverse drama I've watched it really is like no other drama I binged it in two days it kept me hooked first episode hopefully there is a second season because whilst the concept was gruesome and inhumane I really enjoyed watching it.

Engaging from start to end. Exciting, shocking, yet with a fresh and unique storyline that's delightful to watch and visually pleasing. Actors play amazing performances. I could compare to hunger games, but probably 10 times better.

Squid Game Season 1 became hugely popular due to the entertaining value of games themselves, but I highly value its provocation.  I just watched Season 2, and the show keeps asking the audience: what choice would you make? The main argument between Front Man (representing the Game) and Gi-hoon is whether the participation in the Game is by choice or not. Front Man argues that the Game is 100% voluntary since people sign up to participate. Some players, even when they learned about the risk of playing the Game and had a chance to leave the game, chose not to leave.  But nothing exists out of context in reality. Players decide to join the game because they are stuck in serious troubles, often a large amount of debt. Debt is not the only issues in their lives. Usually certain misfortune in a person's life puts them in debt: addiction, gambling, fraud, failure of business, hospital bills, etc. Debt is only added to these issues, followed by violent loan sharks.  When a person has to choose between continuing to endure an extremely painful life and risking life to end the pain, can we call it a 'choice'? If so, isn't our society too harsh on so many people who have similar lives to those of the players in Squid Game?  By presenting an exaggerated situation, Squid Game makes us face the reality that many people live among us and around us. Following the empathetic and righteous Gi-hoon's steps, we get to ask ourselves, "what would I have done if I were in his shoes?"  + production design, camera work, acting are all fabulous!

The Squid game is probably one of the best shows I have seen in a long long time. It sure knows how to play around with the viewer's emotions. It will make you fall in love with some of the characters and then break your heart by killing them off in creative ways.  Its a tough show to watch simply because you will be fully invested and immersed well enough into the story for it to make an impact on you.  Great Character development - Check Perfect Casting - Check Perfect screenplay and progression - Check   A brilliant show that is a must watch, that will make you root for the characters, cry for them and generally start to question their morality, motivations and choices.  And that's what the show is all about. The ethical choices we have to make just to be selfish, just to survive one more day in this cruel cruel world.  I will not give away the plot but would instead implore you to watch the show by yourself and form your own opinions.
Entertaining and demonstrating human nature via this drama. My conclusion is not to be poor otherwise become a chess from rich.

Season 1 is good but S2 is boring. Wouldn't recommend. Not worth the wait. Unnecessary drama and only 3 games.  Even tho acting and cinematography is good But story gets pulled like a chewing gym with nothing unique or amazing to keep hooked.  The story is nor as exiciting as 1st season Netflix just threw money to creators for new season I don't think the creators actually wanted to do this. I had to fast forward many times because the pace was slow and nothing new adding up.  I wish they took more time to make but made a better show.  Episode 3 and 4 are good. Watch 8th show or alice in wonderland instead.

Squid Game has a very high body count, and lots of gore to go with it. But even while the blood is spattering, the focus is on the characters, their relationships with each other, and the mysteries they're unraveling. The attention to detail in every aspect of the series elevates it from enjoyable and entertaining to truly exceptional.  The sets in the Game are mostly simple, with a childish surreality. Yet also artfully designed for the impact that they have, and exquisitely memorable.  Usually when the acting is good, we don't notice or think about it. But there were several times that actors displayed their emotions which such perfectly controlled subtlety that you have to stop to admire it: the uncontrollably trembling chin of an actor pushing himself to the edge of tears to do honor to the scene, or an actor's blank face with the character's emotions "betrayed" by only the twitching of one eye.  Needless to say, the directing and production must have also been top-notch to create these scenes and put them together to tell such a simple but compelling story. The emotional impact is also carefully crafted: somehow, in the midst a huge number of violent deaths, the audience is left sobbing for half of an episode as both developed and undeveloped characters face impending death.  And ultimately, there is a fairly clear moral to the story. But that will have more impact if it's seen and felt, instead of described here.

I am at the 3rd episode in a row! This is really entertaining in a good manner of modern Korean mystery dramas. Well done, usually I am quite skeptical about Netflix shows but this one is truly good one. Enjoy!
This show?! I have no words?! Really good 10/10!! I am amazed.

Last century misogyny, foul language, ageism, casual racism, greed and despair - basically everything that's wrong with South Korea today, and which would be outright rejected if this was a Hollywood/Western production. It's amazing how a few bits of cheap brightly coloured scenery and silly costumes can get people excited about what is a very old and trite concept. Yawn.
I don't know what to say except this series is perfection. It's original and it draws you in if you give it a chance.

So Season 1 was great because the series brought new vibe into Netflix Originals and the main idea of the series is so good, it contains so much potential to be a top tier show. Sadly the world building and the staging started on top level but kept getting worse every single Episode.  The main plot(twist) from last Episode in case was good but they formed it a little bit predictable in my opinion (either because of their exaggerated or too transparent portrayal/focus on individual characters).  Second Season started very good, because some characters have the same level of knowledge as we do and we can empathize better. Again sadly it is to say that it got way faster worse than the first season. The plots are to predictable and the adaptation of the lore through recurring characters is simply too boring.  I am unfortunately disappointed and therefore my personal reviews/ratings of Squid Game are as follows:  Season 1 : 6.3/10 Season 2 : 4.1/10  Overall: 5.1/10.

Squid Game started as a gut punch. Its first season shocked audiences with an explosive mix of violence, social critique, and characters as extreme as they were relatable. Beyond the morbid appeal of deadly trials, what really gripped viewers was how it spoke of debt, desperation, and humanity. It wasn't just entertainment; it was a wake-up call disguised as a spectacle.  Season two chose to expand the universe, introducing new settings and more layers around the system behind the games. It lost some of the surprise factor, sure, but made up for it with a more ambitious plot and even more elaborate visuals. Some narrative decisions were debatable, but the show remained addictive, unsettling, and at times, brilliant.  The third season brought a powerful close. It was rawer, more introspective, and unafraid to make viewers uncomfortable. While some felt the freshness had faded, this final act managed to land with intelligence and an even darker view of human nature. The writing dove deep into the psychology of the characters, without holding back.  What makes Squid Game remarkable is that even in its weaker moments, it maintains a consistent tone and message. The violence isn't gratuitous-it's brutal, yes, but always purposeful. The aesthetics serve the narrative. Every shot, uniform, and silence carries meaning. That consistency is one of the show's greatest strengths.  As a trilogy, it works. Not every part hits the same, but together, the show holds weight, a clear voice, and a message that stings. Watching the full arc, you begin to understand what the creator meant all along: that the game isn't fiction, but a painfully close metaphor.  In short, Squid Game hasn't just been a global hit-it's one of the boldest, most coherent, and provocative series television has seen in years. The initial shock may not return, but the aftertaste it leaves is lasting, uncomfortable, and hard to shake.

Squid Game's first season is a brilliant, must-see phenomenon. Unfortunately, the subsequent seasons are a masterclass in how to squander potential with some of the worst writing on television.  The plot devolves into lazy clichés; any locked door or complex mechanism is conveniently overcome by shooting it. Character intelligence plummets, especially in fights where a victor will injure their foe, then inexplicably drop their weapon and turn their back. It shatters all tension.  The cast does their best, but even great acting can't save a script that makes its characters this foolish. A huge letdown.

I've never watched a Korean tv show before but decided to give this a try since it looked very intriguing and it definitely did not disappoint! It's got an interesting story plus some crazy and gory themes. I highly enjoyed it from start to finish!

Season 2 is brilliant and so much better than season 1, the acting is much better.  I was blown away when I first started watching this, but as the series went on it got a bit tedious, and some of the acting was terrible, especially from the woman who had the lighter, she almost made me want to abandon the whole series.  There is some good acting though, and the idea of the series is very good and interesting.  I'd like this to be re-made by the Americans, I think it would definitely be interesting.
Top everything, go watch it, no seriously, this show was it for me.  10/10.

The problem with a mini series that starts out as good as this one is, it's really hard to keep the same intensity for eight more episodes. The first episode is arguably the most intense and shocking 55 minutes ever filmed. So there's bound to be a drop off. Even so, the entire series is extremely watchable and even binge worthy. If you're looking for something different... THIS IS IT !!

Story Line of season 2 was moving with very slow pace and most of the part of series was expected, also the ending it very vague, At least it should have been ended with come conclusion but the story line is completely open for third season.  The story could have been ended it some concluding way but letting just a small window open for third season but it seems to be opened on all fronts. Also during the games being played and after the game the story was bit boring and was being tuned on a expected line which forced me to fast forward the scenes and same discussion being happening after every game.

I want to dedicate this review just for episode 6 which involves a marble game.  Episode 6 is the greatest piece of emotional rollercoaster i have ever watched. This episode is depressing, shocking, tender, furious, helpless, funny, intelligent and cunning. Unbelievably good and sick!  Just this episode alone deserves an award for the team.  Overall, it's a great series even though personally i didn't like the last 2 episodes.

I came into this with high hopes being a fan of Korean and Asian cinema and was not disappointed. I wouldn't honestly put this up there with Train To Busan - it had the same level of character development - you genuinely care what happens to these characters. It also has a battle royale meets would you rather meets hostel vibe. Just don't watch it dubbed, stick with the original Korean and subtitles.

Season 1 was about an 8/10. This season delivered solid storytelling, great and interesting characters, and had memorable visuals, and emotional depth. It introduced iconic moments like "Red Light, Green Light" and the dalgona candy game, which quickly became viral sensations online. Overall, it was a creative and impactful start that set a high bar for the series.  Season 2 was about a 5/10. This season had a few decent moments and some continuation of the original thrill, but it lacked the intensity and emotional weight of season one. While the games were still somewhat interesting, the storytelling felt inconsistent, and the overuse of awkward or ill-fitting background music made many scenes feel forced or cringeworthy.  Season 3 was about a 3/10, Aside from the hide-and-seek episode, which stood out as a rare highlight, the rest of the season felt rushed and poorly executed. The same background music as season 2 was added which made the scenes awful, and distracting, the VIPs was horrible, and the plot was filled with unrealistic elements, and the overall story arc felt lazy, like an uninspired attempt to wrap up the series. By the end, it felt like a waste of time compared to the potential shown in season one.  To end this off I would suggest to watch all of Season 1 and then not bother watching the other Seasons.

It's like. Season 1 was the best season. Okay, we move on to Season 2. Ehh it's alright. I think Season 2 served as build up for season 3. Which, is the second best season. Season 3 is the season where the writers really put everything in it. Where season 2 fell was that, it lacked climax. Nothing felt scary, we knew everyone was going to live, it lacked the Squid Game of it. But season 3 wow. I haven't felt this invested in Squid Game since 2021! It's amazing. Everything is done well, the suspense. The feeling of not knowing who's going to die. It's all just. Perfect. Perfect. Season 3 is amazing!

Squid Game isn't easy viewing at all; and I believe that it was meant to make viewers uncomfortable and distressing as all hell, because that's what desperation with life-and-death situations are truly like, and it can actually break who we are as people.  456 players, 45.6 billion South Korean won, six games, and only ONE player can come out as the grand champion after everyone else has been killed. To make matters even worse these people were kidnapped off the streets because of their debts to collectors, yet outside the world is far more unforgiving than the brutal takes on classic kid's games.  Netflix managed to strike gold with this show, which I guess took off because of the pandemic's devastating effects on ALL of society, and the themes of desperation and survival resonated with anyone and everyone who tuned into this breakaway mega-hit. It got people so invested it became a massive meme, where people parodied the thing, cooked up fan-theories and mocking the show's all-English dub.  In spite of the showy production values in Squid Game, the characters are still very much like real people who've got real frustrations, real tension inside them, and very real everyone-for-themselves urgency to their character arcs. Squid Game is still a grounded story in spite of its SELECT sci-fi/spy-fi trappings and comic-book-like iconography with the 'PlayStation Men' and mysterious leader.  Squid Game is Netflix's unexpected phenomenon; and I reckon there'll be those who understand and appreciate it and those who won't.  Memes or no memes, this is a show definitely worth your time.

Take Battle Royale, Alice in Borderland, and Ultimate Survivor Kaiji - put them in a blender with all the best parts of each - BOOM you get Squid Game. Incredible plot, great acting (yea the English VIPs were awful, but not enough to the people who are complaining about them in reviews), and the intensity...wonderful series.

Greetings from Lithuania.  I liked and enjoyed "Squid Game" (2021) series for its interesting and simple concept which at the end of the day was very solidly executed. Acting was very solid, as well as directing and writing. The whole concept felt fresh and kinda original and it was easy to get attached and watch the whole show. Ending was also pretty interesting, although a bit predictable.  Overall, i enjoyed "Squid Game". It felt fresh and was involving as well being believable throughout. I believe that given its popularity it will get more seasons. As long as they will be solid as the first one, I'm in for this show.

People are overestimating this series in a way never seen before, it's just an average series, basically this series takes several movies and series and mixes them all together, the only game that's really interesting to watch is the first one.

I found Squid Game a hard show to put down. Once you immerse yourself within this show it feels all too real and scary. I find dark shows more engrossing perhaps because they seem realistic and possible. Human nature has a dark and sometimes unforgiving side. This is why shows like Squid game and Black Mirror trend compared to very PG and convenient shows where the good guys always win.  Another thing to celebrate here is diversity and globalisation. Squid game, being a Korean show which is set in Korea with Korean actors has broken viewing records. The power of Netflix, through its streaming, has crossed international boundaries and reached so many people. We didn't need to see big Hollywood names or familiar settings in New York or LA. Korea and its brand of actors delivered a great show. Borders in a sense have been broken, coincidentally in a time when a virus physically forces them to close.  This show was thought provoking and makes you ask really think about life in general. We're all trying to get rich. But being rich doesn't buy happiness nor does it buy you health.

It has great suspenful moment and with decent to good character development. Due to this, a lot of the character death are painful to watch. It's definitely reccomended for those who love thriller. Plotwise, I would say it's decent enough to keep u watching and drive the story forward.
For me is the best Kdrama in Netflix. So refreshing, thrilled, gore at the same time. Is really mind blowing. 2 thumbs up for this drama!

I have just finished it watching and I have no words to describe it. Trust me when I say this , It is probably the best thing I have ever seen. Story, acting , casting , production everything is very apt and top notch. I can't believe how perfect of a show is this. It is extreme in every human nature they portrayed like when they want to show you hate , friendship, trust , action, backstabbing every emotion is of very extreme kind. It also teaches us that money is not everything. Those who have money and those who don't are sad in one way or the other & We should help others no matter what. I will give it 10 out 10. All hail to Korea for this treat. Love from India 🇮🇳

Sorry. That's a crude summation of this brilliant series. It's a brutal, tense satire on the economic systems we are all trapped in. Would those who lose most at the game, who gamble and get into debt far beyond what they can repay as wage slaves, would they risk their lives to be free? Of course; they would play the Squid Game.  Motivations and characters are carefully fleshed out. The concept of the games we play as children having life & death consequences in adult life is intelligently, deviously developed. It combines quality, international art house drama style with thrills & bloody horror. If you're ready for something challenging and intense play the Squid Game.
We go through all the emotions in front of this series.  One of the best show ever made, Netflix or otherwise.
It had good moments till vip episode but overall games sucked and too childish and then the ending and last few episodes sucked..........................

Squid game was made not for entretainment but to spread a message about society.  This show shows how capitalism manufactures desperation as a condition for its survival. It reveals that people aren't inherently greedy or violent; they're forced into a blood sport when society denies them basic necessities like dignity, housing, and healthcare unless they "earn it." Also, needless to say, it critiques the system and how it affects people from different economic situations, those suffering under poverty, debt and humiliation are treated as inferior to the rich, who end up gambling with them.  Season 1 of Squid Game is, without a doubt, one of the greatest series of all time. When it was released, it was revolutionary; cinematographically and artistically amazing. One of its biggest strengths was its original concept, something never seen before. Thanks to the excellent writing, which is the pilar of the show, the characters felt human and believable, each representing different struggles within society. The pacing was perfect, with thrilling mystery at its heart, and importantly, it avoided clichés and never lost its essence. The striking production design gave the show a unique personality, something rare today and still iconic. But what stood out the most was its powerful social commentary.  Because Season 1 set the bar so high, Season 2 had a tough job, and it managed to reach those standards quite well. Season 2 introduced new characters who became the core of the story. It also gave fans an inside look at the games, which was fun but sometimes made the original mystery feel faded. The season respected the legacy, but there were still things to criticize. Unlike the strong finale of Season 1, Season 2 ended with a disappointing cliffhanger. Visually, the finale was impressive, but emotionally it lacked the shocking impact and moral depth that made the first season unforgettable. Instead of a bold ending, it felt more like a setup for the next season. This finale also started a violent, chaotic trend that led to the catastrophic third season.  Season 3 is, by far, the worst of all. The show seems to have lost its purpose. The waste of some characters is frustrating, and others act in ways that feel dumb, meaningless, and hard to relate to. The police subplot, which was supposed to be important, turns out useless. The season feels rushed and tries to create a meaningful and impactful story but ends up doing the opposite. The writing quality has dropped, and ironically, the whole team seems blinded by money and greed.  Season 3 reveals almost nothing new about the mysterious organization or the games. Instead of fresh secrets or deepening the story, it repeats old conflicts and recycles familiar plots. This lack of new information makes the season feel stagnant and repetitive, leaving fans frustrated and disappointed. Without real surprises or bold twists, the suspense and excitement that once defined the series fade away.  And the finale? It really makes my blood boil. The return of the leader and his brother, plus the police storyline, was wasted. The baby subplot is horrible - they spent too much money on that instead of improving other parts. Words can't describe how depressing the last game is. By that point, the show had lost all its original essence.  Squid Game started as a groundbreaking and unforgettable series, setting high standards in storytelling, design, and social commentary. But as the seasons progressed, it lost its way. Season 2 struggled to maintain the mystery and emotional power, while Season 3 sacrificed quality and meaning for shock value and recycled ideas. Player 456 will remain one of the bests in history, and all the memes, iconic things and whatever won't be forgotten, I've had the time of my life laughing in a tik tok comment section. Once again the iconicness of a show impacts its quality.  But sadly,in the end, a once brilliant show faded into a shadow of its former self, leaving fans disappointed and longing for the fresh, original spark that made it great, because, again, ironically money always wins.
This is one of my best short series of all time, it is so attaching and make you wanna finish it in one day, yes it is so violent and scenes might really disturb you, but.... I love it.

Season 3 isn't just a continuation-it's a reset button and a revenge plan in motion. And I have to admit: I was skeptical. Season 2 left me with more questions than satisfaction, but Season 3? It's bolder. Darker. Smarter. And it brings back what I loved in Season 1-the human stakes.  This isn't just about surviving anymore. It's about fighting back.  ✅ What I Loved in Season 3  1. Gi-hun's new arc feels earned This is no longer the same man who barely made it out. He's laser-focused and walking the razor's edge between justice and obsession. The choices he makes now are uncomfortable-and that's exactly why I was hooked.  "To kill the game, I might have to become the game."  2. A deeper look into the system We finally get more of the hierarchy: the Inner Circle, the legacy of the Front Man, and the sick logic behind the entire operation. Season 3 doesn't just show the games-it shows how they're built. And who benefits.  3. The new games are twisted in the best way Let's just say: they got even more sadistic with simplicity. One involves truth-telling in a way that breaks people mentally before the game even starts. Another is a twist on trust-falls that had me yelling "NO WAY" at the screen.  4. High emotional impact returns Season 3 brought back the heartbreak of Season 1. There's a marble-level moment again. And yeah... it hit. Hard. I didn't expect to cry, and then I did. Again.  ❌ What Didn't Work for Me  1. Pacing still stutters mid-season Episodes 4 and 5 drag. It tries to get philosophical and loses some momentum. I respect it, but I felt the slowdown.  2. A few new characters felt underdeveloped There's one female player who seems crucial early on-then fades. It's like they forgot to give her a third act. That annoyed me.  3. The twist villain was a little too obvious I saw it coming three episodes ahead. Not that it ruined it-but I was hoping for a gut-punch surprise.  🌟 Final Thoughts  8.7 out of 10 Squid Game: Season 3 feels like the series finding itself again-gritty, strategic, and emotionally brutal. It answers a lot. It dares to ask more. And by the finale, I felt both shaken and satisfied. If Season 1 was survival, and Season 2 was fallout, then Season 3 is the counterattack we've been waiting for.  It's not perfect-but it's back.  🎥 If You Liked This, You Might Also Enjoy: 1. Alice in Borderland - Season 2 (Netflix) - Strategic survival with high stakes  2. Black Mirror: "White Bear" - Morality and punishment twisted into a game  3. The Platform (2019) - Brutal social allegory with life-and-death decisions  4. 3% - Season 3 (Netflix) - More rebellion, more layers  5. The Purge: The Series - Power, control, and the illusion of freedom.

All the praise for this "brilliant" series, full of "original" ideas. Go read The Long Walk and The Running Man by Richard Bachman (i.e. Stephen King). The Long Walk was the first novel he wrote (but not the first of his that was published)...it's over 50 years old, and was published over 40 years ago. Nearly everything this series is built on can be found there in a simpler format.

If you watched any of the most recent dystopian movie likes Hunger Games then you can pretty much figure out that no one is going to win in this. It is made clear that there is only going to be one winner so all the supposed teams are going to end badly so the friendships made are for the sole purpose of making the audience feel something. It kinda does work but it makes you feel manipulated at the same time.  This is not a bad show and I can see why people like it. It has all parts to a great Netflix Original but I just felt manipulated while watching it.

Episode 1 was AMAZING!!!  But things went downhill a little bit each episode. By episode 4, I was totally over it.  I did watch all 9 episodes, because I'd already invested so much time into it. Plus, I wanted to see what all the social media hype was about...unfortunately, after all 9 episodes, I'm not seeing it.  Didn't really need to be 9 hours long...would of worked better as one regular 90-minute film.

With a premise similar to the likes of Cube and Circle, the odd titled Squid Game helps us question humanity all over again as well as the importance society places on money.  As dark and violent as Battle Royal and intriguing as 3% it grabs your attention early on and keeps you guessing to the end.  Great binge worthy series with a likeable cast and main protagonist.  Knocked off one point as I didn't love the ending but otherwise a really great TV series with some great ideas and worthy of top marks.  Season 2? Personally I think it works better as a one off but then again...

Honestly, Squid Game was one of the best shows I've ever seen, every detail has a deep reason, and it shows something that the director is trying to tell the audience. It represents a real-life story, not just some fake where it knows that the audience will like. By the end, you will not just have felt like you had a good time, you will have changed and become a better person. Despite what some people have said about the show being overrated, since they didn't get their desired ending. I think the show is great as it is. The series is a form of communication to explore and communicate the ideas of the director and people should try to understand that. The only bad thing to say is that the VIPs are bad. They don't have any character, and their lines aren't delivered with any actual thought and seem empty.

The first season of Squid Game is 9/10, it was groundbreaking, gripping, and close to perfection. Each episode delivered shocking twists, defied expectations, and kept viewers hooked from beginning to end.  While the second season didn't quite reach the heights of the first, I still found it compelling and fitting for the direction the series was taking. The characters were developed with care, though I personally found Kang No-eul's character less engaging than the rest (same for season 3).  Season three, however, was a noticeable step back. Apart from the game sequences, the season largely felt disappointing. The storyline moved at a much slower pace compared to previous seasons, lacking the dark humor and "tragicomic" moments that had become a signature of the show. It leaned heavily into drama, which made it feel tonally different and somewhat unbalanced.  One of the most puzzling decisions was sidelining Seong Gi-hun. His role felt unusually passive, with limited dialogue and scarce screen time until the very last episode. The other main storyline was serviceable but also predictable. On a positive note, I think Front Man's transformation was handled effectively. However, the show seemed to go overboard in trying to portray the VIP characters as ridiculous or evil, it came off as forced and sometimes outright absurd.  As for the finale, it offered closure by completing the character arcs of both Seong Gi-hun and the Front Man. Although satisfying in a broad sense, the ending felt a bit too simple for a series of this scale and ambition. It could have benefited from a more daring or thought-provoking conclusion.

I binge-watched this one. Every episode was so addictive and tense.  All episodes were very emotionnal. Then we reached the conclusion and.... what a letdown. Huge anti-climatic ending.  I would still recommend watching it.

The sereal started very interesting. You dont know why happening this, who is behind this, and what kind of child game thay will play. But after episode 7 when the vip-s arrived, the whole concept are turnd up side down. All the serial become predictible, like im feeling my self as a precog. Who is the vip-s, who is the firshand whatever. That makes from 8 star to 7. But is still a good seral. A new type of battle royale. But the most annoying thing is, the concept was the child games, and that is gone when the vip-s was arrived. Why this concept changed? That was the moment when i changed my mind ftom 7 to 6 star. And of course the vip-s are super lame, but the concept change are way more worst than bad acting.
Sure, it's a complete rip-off of a Japanese classic movie but it's still one of the most imaginative and visually stunning shows this year.  Love it.  Watch it!

Season 2 Review -  One of the biggest global releases of this year, the anticipation for the new season was at an all-time high. It is a Herculean task to match the monumental expectations of fans, and thus, this season falls short compared to the previous one.  This season focuses on Gi-Hun, who, after winning 45.6 billion, returns to the game-not to win, but to put an end to it. His mission is to eliminate those orchestrating the games, exploiting vulnerable people on the brink of suicide due to their debts or financial struggles for their own twisted entertainment.  The season starts strong, picking up exactly where the previous one left off, with a promising storyline to take forward. The first two episodes set up the premise well, building anticipation for adrenaline-pumping games. However, that's where the disappointment sets in. This time, there are two new games, one of which includes five smaller games. Unfortunately, none of these matches the thrill or intensity of last season's challenges, leaving fans underwhelmed.  Lee Jung-jae, as the lead, continues to showcase his acting prowess. This season, his transformation into a more confident individual is portrayed convincingly. Lee Byung-hun, who was behind the mask last season, gets more screen time and delivers a commendable performance. Yang Mal-bok, a new character playing a mother in the game, elevates the series' emotional quotient. Additionally, other new characters, including T. O. P and Lee David, play their respective parts well.  The makers introduce interesting characters with solid characterizations, but their contributions to the narrative feel lacking. With so many new faces, the storyline becomes confusing, and the focus on characters plotting or seeking revenge takes away from the thrill and excitement of the games.  The season's ending is its biggest letdown-abrupt, as if someone turned off the screen mid-story. Neither the plot nor the games conclude satisfactorily, leaving viewers with more questions and, ultimately, frustration. While it sets the stage for another season, the unresolved storylines and lack of closure can feel irritating after investing so much time.  Watch this season if you're a fan of the series, but be prepared for a bit of disappointment as it doesn't measure up to the brilliance of Season 1.  #PranuReviews #SquidGames2 #SquidGames2Review #SquidGamesSeason2 #SquidGamesSeason2Review.

First off the main character is unlikeable. I wasn't rooting for him the entire show. He's not exactly a good person and came off as annoying.  Second, it took a LONG TIME for anything interesting to happen. The establishing backstory was very boring and very unnecessary. They could have told us everyone's stories in a couple of quick flashbacks and gone straight into the action!  Third, this is not an original concept. I've seen this type of social commentary done a thousand times in a thousand different ways.  Do yourself a favor and go watch Alice in Borderland. It's a much better show.

The second season of this series is an absolute letdown and feels like a blatant scam aimed at milking viewers for their time and money. From start to finish, it's clear that the creators had no solid plan or meaningful content to deliver. Instead, they resorted to stretching out episodes with filler material, dragging out scenes, and splitting games across multiple episodes just to pad the runtime. The entire season feels like a pointless slog, with no real progression or payoff. It's as if the writers were just winging it, pulling ideas out of thin air without any thought for coherence or entertainment value.  The games themselves are either repetitive or downright weak, lacking the creativity and intensity that made the first season engaging. One particular game was so poorly designed and nonsensical that it seemed solely intended to waste screen time and eliminate as many characters as possible. It was a lazy attempt to create drama without putting in the effort to craft something compelling. The season's pacing is atrocious, with most episodes feeling like a chore to sit through. Instead of building tension or developing characters, the show meanders aimlessly, leaving viewers frustrated and bored.  To make matters worse, the season ends on a cliffhanger, with the resolution of the central game pushed to the third season. This decision feels like a cheap trick to force viewers to keep watching, rather than a natural storytelling choice. It's clear that the creators are more interested in prolonging the series than delivering a satisfying narrative. Overall, the second season is a massive disappointment, filled with filler, weak content, and a lack of respect for the audience's time. It's a prime example of how to ruin a promising show by prioritizing profit over quality. Save yourself the frustration and skip this season entirely.
I really enjoyed it and suggest this series to everyone I know! Perfect.

Squid Game is a savage yet gripping commentary on human nature, survival, and the cost of desperation in a world ruled by systemic inequality. The show doesn't hold back in its portrayal of how far people are willing to go to escape financial ruin and the moral compromises they make along the way.  What struck me the most was how the games stripped away layers of social pretense, exposing raw instincts-both noble and vile. While some characters clung to fragments of humanity, others succumbed to their darkest impulses, reminding me of how power and greed can distort even the kindest souls. The juxtaposition of the innocent childhood games with the horrifying stakes was as unsettling as it was genius, hammering home the twisted nature of the system.  But the series also explores the concept of choice-or the illusion of it. The players chose to return, but did they ever truly have a choice? The game mirrored the world outside: brutal, competitive, and indifferent to morality.  As a fan of psychological thrillers, Squid Game ticked all the boxes, but it also left me reflecting on how complicit we all are in systems that perpetuate inequality. While watching, I couldn't help but think about the parallels between this fictional world and our reality. Perhaps the most haunting part isn't the violence but how relatable the desperation feels.  This show sticks with you, forcing you to question not just the characters' choices but your own values as well.  Visually, the series is a feast for the eyes and fun in design. The bold use of color-the eerie pinks, greens, and reds-contrasts sharply with the dark themes, creating a surreal yet unnervingly playful aesthetic. The creativity in the set design, from the Escher-inspired staircases to the childlike yet menacing playgrounds, adds a layer of sophistication that mirrors the show's underlying commentary on manipulation and control. Even the costumes-iconic and unsettling in their simplicity-are meticulously crafted to convey power dynamics.

I saw that some people rated Squid Game Season 2 a 1, while giving 5 or 6 stars to many Hollywood shows that are honestly trash. It seems to me that this stems from excessive dissatisfaction with the fact that the season was split into two parts, and that we have to wait until next year to see Season 3. Giving such low ratings just because things don't go exactly the way you want feels a bit childish. While Season 2 might not be as groundbreaking as Season 1, I think it's still enjoyable as a necessary step toward Season 3. It's tough to wait for the next season, but I believe Season 2 gives us plenty to speculate about how the story will conclude. There are tons of hidden clues in this season that set up what's to come, and I hope you all enjoy the fun of discovering them.

Probably one of the most cliché, "battle royale" kind of storyline... BUT... It was still very gripping, intense, and entertaining. Definitely a binge worthy show! I can really see the typical K-drama elements in this show - you know, the unnecessary and far-fetched plot twist that almost makes you feel like it's trying to make up for something? Yeah, that. I could probably list all the cliché and predictable moments in this show but I don't want to spoil it for anyone.  However, I can't deny the fact that this really did get me binge watching for 2 days. Perhaps, it's the great acting or the overly indulgent storyline - I'm not sure but I was hooked.

Netflix has a habit of delivering seasons in two parts; they should have done the same here to avoid any confusion.  Nevertheless, S2 is still a brilliant and worthy continuation of S1. Does it hit the same? Nope, but this is next to impossible to achieve anyway. It picks up where S1 left off and expands our world. Now we see what happens in the control room, we see what happens outside the island, we even get a front-row seat of the Front Man.  S2 is packed with plot twists that had me gaping. The characters are relatable and interesting. Seong Gi-hun gets much-needed character depth. Lee Byung-hun is amazing as Front Man.  The new games could have been a bit more interesting, but if you are mad about that, you are missing the point - the whole aim of these games is to break the MC, Seong Gi-hun. They do not need to be creative, they need to be violent. The voting has the same purpose, to show Seong his side will always lose.  Honestly, the mad reviewers should go back to S1 because they missed a whole lotta points. The rest, give S2 a chance and get ready for the grand finale!

I found it pretty sleepy. Even had to go back and rewatch a few episodes due to having fallen asleep.  I felt there was nothing all that new in it, knew who would win from the start (well duh!), And generally I thought the acting was pretty bad for the most part.  Hype is hype... And this was hype.
The details are in every scene. Wish to see another season.
Maybe the main dude wasn't just so dumb and annoying, half the characters are hard to stand.

Will be a season 3 for definite but not sure I'll bother watching. I'm sure some will enjoy it but it's not for me this time.

Netflix seems to be able to find these "box set"versions of visual cocaine that make one unable to stop the 'next episode' button. This Korean paranoid vision of game show euthanasia does kinda feel like something I'd seen it before, Battle Royale, The Cube, Maze Runner and even The Prisioner spring to mind. However, if you can get past the slightly weird dialogue and the slightly uncomfortable attitude towards women then it's a beautiful looking and engaging series.

A tentacular dystopian vision of the depths those deserted of luck will descend to in order to recover their losses. Combines schadenfreude shades aplenty alongside some outstanding performances while asking some questions you might not want to find an answer to.

One of the best K Netflix series I've seen in recent years. The plot, cinematography, and acting (with the exception of some masked caucasians in the end) was superb. Several A-list actors were in this show and the cameos by them were very well woven into the story.  Although its brutal - its more brutal in what's actually going on, and what's happening - than being graphically brutal.  And you will sit there and feel lots of things - scared and somewhat freaked out as well, and as I said: its Uncomfortably geniusly made in my opinion. Just binged the whole 9 episodes, best thing I've seen on Netflix since I opened my account. Even though it's dubbed, you hardly notice! Watch it, you won't be disappointed!

Many reviewers have commented on the "horrible acting" of the VIPs. I sense their lack of emotion is intentional. It is indicative of their lack of normal human empathy.  Overall I found the story to be interesting and that the story compelled me to continue watching through to the end. In that regard, the production was well done.  The conclusion and theme is not anything that I can praise however. Life is not purposeless nor is everyone bad and lacking in virtue. I have viewed so many Asian films that purport to say "life is futile".  Life is worth living. Life has meaning. That is my hope and faith. So I stand against the theme of the production but I found it interesting and entertaining. Entertainment is its only value.

I agree with others about the VIPs acting and line being awful. I watched it dubbed in English, so it could be translation, or voice acting that went awry. Otherwise the dub was quite good(well for dub standards). I think I'll be watching it a second time with just subtitles.  South Korean cinema has become so popular in the West because it carries a certain gravitas and detail many western movies lack these days. I'm far from a film buff who looks forward to Tribeca or Sundance, but I can confidently say there is a distinct discipline displayed in South Korean films and shows. From the emotions on display by talented actors, to scripts that rely more on showing over telling, to the amazing seeds sown early that lead to payoffs later. And it's all wrapped up in great cinematography.  Squid Game is no different. It might not reach the heights of OldBoy or Parasite or even I saw the Devil, and is a little more predictable. But it is a must watch for fans of South Korean films.

This series revolves around a game show where players have to compete against each other and play simple games to stay alive. Horrible things happen to the people who lose and people can go to any extent to win the game. Back stabbing, treachery become commonplace when your survival depends upon the other players losing the game. This series perfectly depicts the human nature when they are pitched against each other.  I love the fact that the makers have carefully chosen each game in such a way that though these are kids games, they can lead to a terrible fight among the players and show the true nature of each of them. However, I think since the season 1 is a blockbuster hit, they are now trying to drag the story for seasons after seasons. If this continues after 3-4 seasons, boredom would kick in.

Battle Royale, As The Gods Will (literally about kid's games in a death challenge environment), Alice in Borderland, Hunger Games, etc. And those are just the Asian ones...  This really didn't do anything special or anything unique. The story dragged on during some moments, wouldn't be surprised if they were trying to stretch out the episodes. Episode 6 was the best one and had some of the show's best acting.  The last 3 episodes were really bad and uninspired and clearly just meant to setup a season 2 which is annoying. All the character arcs are thrown out the window, a police officer investigating this deadly game has a lackluster ending, and the reveals.... meh? The 'protagonist' learns nothing by the end of the film, so there's zero character arc.  I'll give it a 6. It's entertaining to watch the games and their thought process but I can't give it anymore than that thanks to the lackluster ending. Now an ending can be disappointing but I want rate an entire series on JUST an ending (like Game of Thrones). But the fact this did nothing new at all and flat out copied movies. People are saying some of the above movies I mentioned are fantasy, but there's another movie I can't think of where people volunteer to play for money in a very realistic setting that is basically the same thing...  Nothing new, acting is OKAY, some major plotholes or scratch your head moments, and not a good conclusion. I know they're setting up for season 2, but how they set it up is pretty stupid. And I don't think it needs to go there to begin with.
I just created an account to rate this. Perfect korean thriller series! We need more of these.

I loved this show for many reasons. The story was great I loved the concept and characters. The violence and gore was great too. The downfall is the bad acting at times it's kinda laughable bad. Overall a great surprise and I want more seasons even if it's with a new cast. I want more !!!

Really great show. Loved it but found it strange like so many others that the VIP actors are so horrible bad in delivering their lines. It's almost if Tommy Wiseau and the cast from The Room hid behind the VIP masks. Anyway I can live with the bad acting in that episode because everything else is just fantastic.

The live or death game is not thrill anymore, its just fun and predictable that's why i dont enjoy it much i know they want to show new game but for what i see its not more thrill than 1st season, just like watch a gaming episodes in a tv show like running man, its just fun and enjoyable.  Once again its just my opinion, i'm not a profesional reviewer or something else, just a regular fans from this series that waiting much long from the 1st season.

The decision making of the characters is painfully bad and most of the acting is over done and cringey. There are also random side stories and characters that have absolutely no relevance to the show.

A series that combines artistic creativity, visual creativity, and genius in the acting performances of the heroes of the work, which rises to be the best series I have watched produced by Netflix, despite the dark side of the story. I also can not forget the creativity in choosing classical music and slow songs that calm the soul in sharp and violent scenes, which gives a wonderful taste in that mixture.

I wont say much but just WOW. It has everything I was looking in a series & more.  (Some saying VIPs sucked yeah but that doesn't affect the series much Idk why they're making it a big issue) A total bingeworthy content kudos to the creators & actors.
Unexpected movie, brilliant idea,. This is one of the Best movie this year, Jobwell done !!! Netflix should continue to produce a movie like this.. 👍

As per my title this isn't a very original idea. It's been done time and time again: Highlander (1986), Battle Royale (2000), The Hunger Games (2012), Animal World (2018) etc. The only difference is the venue/place where they are held and the winnings at the end.  I tried to watch this when it first appeared on Netflix, but after 3 episodes it still hadn't impressed me, and was quickly forgotten when I found something better to binge watch. After seeing all the hype about it I decided to give it another go, perhaps I should have given it 4 episodes? Nope it still didn't impress.  I have to question the '111 million fans' claim by Netflix. I'm more inclined to believe it is 111 million 'Viewings' that include the multiple viewings by single individuals or their group friends at home or around at their friends houses when their parents are away. Viewings do not correspond to fans.  The acting is your usual frenetic Korean overacting, overdone facial expressions combined with family honour/disappointment.  The main characters, although given back stories, aren't what you would consider likeable so you don't really invest too much empathy into who will or won't survive, bearing in mind that 'There can be only one' (to quote Highlander) winner at the end of the game.  My only real interest was in working out who was behind the whole setup of 'Squid Game' and who the 'Frontman' was. The clues are there and it didn't take me too long to have a (correct) working theory.  I suppose if you are looking for some 'bloody' entertainment, that you can disengage your brain to watch, then this will meet your needs.  I gave it a generous 6 stars as while it isn't as good as it is hyped to be it certainly isn't as bad as some of Netflix's underwhelming prior offerings.

The VIP actors in Season 2 really dragged the entire series down. Honestly, where did they even find those people? My 9-year-old son could've done a better job! It was almost painful to watch those scenes, and sadly, this isn't the only Korean series that struggles with poor casting for side roles. To the producers of Korean dramas and films: please, just spend 10 dollars more and hire actors who can actually act-it really makes a world of difference in the viewing experience. That said, I still genuinely enjoyed the series. The main cast did a solid job, and the storyline had a strong emotional core that kept me invested. The pacing was tight, the suspense was well-built, and the production quality was top-notch. I especially loved the immersive settings and the bold, creative ideas behind the plot. With just a little more attention to casting minor roles, this could've been an all-time great. Still, it's definitely worth watching.

Im soo glad i watched this before all the hype started because shows are always ruined by hype and spoilers. Being completely new to korean telly, i was shockingly surprised by the story line, the drama, the acting, the cinematics and the entire shabang! Its the best series i have seen in a very very long time but i do feel it will be a one hit wonder. A season 2 just wont be able to match up to the buzz & excitement surrounding Season 1.

The director seems intent on exhausting every possible configuration of tension, showing each micro-reaction: hesitation, betrayal, alliance, regret, flashback... This exhaustive exploration enriches the storytelling and gives each episode rare emotional density. However, it sometimes feels like the sequence of events is secondary, as long as the final outcome is achieved (who dies, who survives). This approach weakens surprise and makes some developments predictable-even formulaic.

It's probably been said enough by now, but this show just isn't worth watching past Season 1.  If the creators were determined to expand the SG universe, I would've preferred a prequel exploring how the games began, especially through the lens of a young Player 1.  But honestly, with talent like this, I wish they had told a completely new story outside the SG universe. Something with a fresh lesson, the same emotional weight, and the creativity that made Season 1 so impactful.  Instead, we got what feels like a cash grab, with recycled themes and hollow echoes of what worked the first time.  I'm still interested in what these creators do next. I just hope the SG universe has finally reached its end.
I don't usually review, but when I do, It is really really good.

It is disturbing in a way that why the hell is happening this ?  But I have to say that the plot is unique ( Not in a good way or bad way but very dark grey i guess ).  Okay, At last my opinion is one should watch this.
Loved every episode. Give it a chance. Definitely not the same ol crud that gets pumped out over and over these days.

It started way much better than it ended and by mid-season the series had too many useless long scenes that didn't help the drama...  The characters build up was good and most of the main characters has depth but all the events are way way too predictable and in too many instances you waste 5 or more minutes of watching things you already know it will happen with no twists happening  Also at the first few episodes it had meaningless flashbacks to things happened literally 3 mins before which made feel weak and and shallow...

I enjoyed Squid Game but feel it's rather overrated. I've been a big fan of far eastern and in particular Japanese and Korean movies for many years. Lady Vengeance and Oldboy in particular stuck with me. So many people have been talking about Squid Game, I was expecting a little bit more. When you know there are twists, even ones you don't expect, they don't really come as a surprise.
Mind blowing, you just can't take your eyes away from the TV for anything.  Loved it and looking forward for season 2, hope it will continue at the same level.

Pros * interesting premise * atmospheric * some of the acting is very well done * some character development is well done  Cons * character personalities change at random * some over the top acting * some overly stereotypical characters * premise doesn't have any real foundation * it ignores the potential sociocultural insight  Pros The story underneath it all is an interesting one. The same general idea isn't a unique one (eg. It's similar to Brazil's "3%"), but the my build in enough sub-plots, mystery, and kind of cliffhanger endings, for it to have a fair bit of intrigue.  The setting also works. Real life scenes in the city are mostly either dark or grey, contrasting with the childlike bright colours and symbols of the games. It's definitely quirky and somewhat atmospheric.  Cons But that's all let down by some weak acting, annoying voice actor in the English dubbed version, and characters either who are too stereotypical or whose personalities change in a whim.  There's some decent acting and character development as well, but it's way overdone (exaggerated facial expressions and 'tantrums') by the main character and a several of the stereotypical ones are where the acting is really overdone.  By the end, when they start revealing the motivations behind it all;m, it gets pretty weak, stereotypical (again), and exaggerated.  In addition to this, there's so much potential for a political or sociocultural commentary. So much scope to address the changes in kids habits (from active and interactive physical and outdoor games and the creativity of making up new ones, to iPad and PC screens all day long). And more so, to address the poor dying and struggling to survive to make money that for most is never actually within their grasp, while the rich do nothing but exploit them. (The latter is what "3%" does really well). But the dialogue doesn't really touch on the issues at all. More focus on blood and guts than on any potential insight.  Overall, too many characters make no sense, and it ultimately feels hollow in the end.

The talk and reviews have me bewildered, I'm only up to Ep3 but am struggling after about 5 attempts to start bingeing.  I find it boring and really childish, with pretty ordinary acting.  The set design, art direction and general production values are very 1970's.  Two more attempts then I'll give up.

WOW, there are so much twists, action, suspense, drama, and messages all packed in 9 episodes. It is hard to stop watching once you started. One of the best Netflix show ever. I really like the ending.

You don't have to be a Korean drama fanatic to enjoy Squid game, it is great, the VIP team is lacking but otherwise everything else is just perfect............okay this isn't actually happening somewhere right 😂😂😂😂😂😂, with the desperation for money currently in the world I wouldn't be surprised🤦

Those of you complaining about the VIPs are completely missing the point. This show is so damn clever. The VIPs are meant to be over the top, gaudy, and obnoxious. They're representing the type of rich, entitled aholes that enjoy this kind of entertainment. These are the same guys that would set up a game of hunting for humans. Fantastic show.

After watching Attack on Titan I felt empty, I couldn't watch netflix anymore.  But this one guys, I don't know what to say. A cult! One of the best and emotional shows ever produced! Episode 6 represents TV at its peak.

The show is so bland! I don't even know where to start. The acting is bad, and the characters do not make sense at the time. There is no depth whatsoever, there is nothing between the lines and the story doesn't add up. I really hope the rating would fall below 7/10 since this doesn't make any sense.

Too many bloody, violences, cruelties, and inappropriate scenes. I suggest that it could be made softer and a bit more elegant, then it could be more interested to watch it. I can only give it 10 starts because I cannot make that movie, but I can help them to make it better.

Squid Game made a massive impact worldwide, drawing attention for its high-stakes survival games and social commentary. The series is undeniably visually striking, with its bold color palette, meticulously designed sets, and tense cinematography creating an immersive dystopian world. The concept of ordinary people competing in deadly childhood games is initially gripping and emotionally charged, showcasing desperation, moral dilemmas, and the lengths humans will go to survive.  However, after closer examination, the show feels somewhat overrated. While it received immense global acclaim, many elements are familiar, and the narrative is not particularly innovative. Survival game plots with social critique have been explored in literature and media before, and Squid Game does not significantly expand on these ideas. Some plot twists feel predictable, and certain character arcs are underdeveloped, leaving emotional beats less impactful than intended.  Despite these criticisms, the performances are solid, especially from Lee Jung-jae and HoYeon Jung, whose portrayals bring depth to the main characters. The series also succeeds in reflecting social inequality, greed, and human vulnerability, but the exploration is occasionally heavy-handed, sacrificing nuance for shock value.  In conclusion, Squid Game is entertaining and visually memorable, but its global hype may overstate its originality and storytelling depth. While it captures attention and provides intense, binge-worthy moments, the series ultimately feels somewhat formulaic and less groundbreaking than the media frenzy suggests.  Rating: 6/10 - A compelling watch, but not as revolutionary as its reputation claims.
I totally love it so i will give it 10/10. A s a matter of fact all actors were incredible in their acting but the vib were not.

I confess to watching every episode before realizing the characters were an overused, worn-out personality mix, the plot was predictable and the hundreds of assassination style killings were the central plot driver.  But still part me enjoyed the novelty, the exposure of human fragilities and the bright color sets and costuming.  The product is not that great, the remarkable popularity might be explained by the economic desperation many of us feel right now and perhaps it taps into a growing resentment toward the financial elite.

The fact that this new series has recently been considered the latest cult hit and the reviews (including the established critics) celebrate this stuff is once again a sign of the stupidity and abstinence from reflection in modern times of the 21st century. So much is wrong with this series, yes, the whole idea behind it, that I hardly know where to start. But I'll try. The purely cinematic criticism first: The character development is ad hoc, in rapid succession and hardly comprehensible. The character development from the failed and disliked clown to the moral hero does not work and is wrapped in a bad script. The supporting characters are just vehicles and not much else. Scattered in to show humanity, friendship or criminal energy and ruthlessness here and there, they are ultimately not figures in themselves. The cinematography is okay, but far too obsessed with a disgusting aesthetic, which is so full of wealth, greed and hedonism that it is not the renunciation of such anti-values, but their celebration. The music / the score are completely irrelevant and immature. They have no influence on the film. The script has as many gaps as a Swiss cheese and storylines go untold. The actors are sometimes like that, but all in all they tend to be in the lower range of the theatrical talent factory. They often only convey one, and when the going gets tough, maybe two or three qualities that the script exploits like wood engravings. Aside from these obvious aspects, however, the worst thing about this entire series is its game of hide-and-seek. The producers and creators of the series pretend that they are telling a parable about wealth, unscrupulousness, greed for money and, in the ultimate end, a moral story about ethics, humanity and humanism, but aim at a target group that is not aimed at them in the same breath Interested in topics. Instead, the show should (and will be) driven to success by a target group that is fascinated by the sadism, the ruthlessness and the immeasurable wealth of a brutal game of chance. The last episode underlines this ridiculousness impressively. A game of double standards and also pure greed for money takes place here. Artistic? Love for the medium of film? Or an affection for pop culture? None of it. I have a hard time expressing how much I hate this series because the disgust at the partying reactions takes my breath away. Our world, like ancient Rome, seems to perish on the disgusting hedonism of our time. Have fun and welcome to the Squid Games. I'm out.

Squid Game Season 2 is a thrilling continuation of the original, maintaining the suspense and social commentary that made its predecessor a global phenomenon. The new games are even more elaborate and deadly, pushing the boundaries of human endurance and morality. The characters, both new and returning, are complex and morally gray, forcing viewers to question their own values in the face of extreme circumstances. While some may find the violence excessive, it serves to highlight the brutal realities of poverty and desperation that drive individuals to participate in such a deadly game. Overall, Squid Game Season 2 is a captivating and thought-provoking series that will leave viewers on the edge of their seats.
Nothing to say about it. Just wanted to say go and watch this series. This is ridiculous and awesome series I have ever seen.

"Squid Game" is definitely a slow burn in its first 2 episodes (but they do give you a taste of what's to come). As for the rest of the season, you probably won't be able to stop watching thanks to its story, characters, thrills, twists, games and, of course, gore.

The First Season is a blast!  Re-watched it before Season 2, and damn, it hold its title as one of the best tv show out there.  The first time I heard squid game was from a friend when it first came out, and I was neither interested in checking it out or watching it (even the first episode); but there was this time that some of our friends wanted to stream the show, and I obliged (a friendly gesture) to stream it for them. And oh boy! The first episode HOOKED me on the show, and kept coming back!  Re-watching it makes it even more compelling, finally understanding the concept of the show and admire its complexity.

The series is great and worth the watch. I have to admit I already called the twist by the second episode, but the journey was great. The latter part of the season lost its way with some heavy cringe characters but I'll look past that. My biggest gripe comes with the latter part becoming cliché and in violation of what previous episodes had laid down, as in everyone has a fair shot at winning whereas the game they played was in gross violation of that (episode 7). Give it a watch though.

As a whole, Squid Game is a incredible show. However, as always with Netflix's greed, the show went downhill after S1. S1 was dark, but it also gave viewers the time to get attached to its characters, and the shock factor. However, as S2 arguably got split into 2, the series became less hard hitting and emotional. Towards the end, I felt like most of the characters growth in S2 was reversed, and their deaths were massively rushed and therefore less impactful. The last 20 minutes of S3 were not what I expected. However, the acting, suspense, and creativity involved in this show means that I can't rate it lower than a 7.

Season one was original and interesting and terrifying. I must admit to violent for my taste, but a very intriguing and gripping story. Everything past that was a complete and utter let down. They basically just rehashed season one while adding a multitude of storylines over laying it to expand the universe, not to any benefit. Artistically some amazing and beautiful shots.
