So it's a John Wick or Hardcore-esque action flick with some virus nonsense side plot, however you see from the very first fight the main character is involved in that he is NEVER in danger, The opening fight scene is "Carter" naked fighting circa 30-60 gangsters with bladed weapons and not a single cut on him, additionally they had him down as a CIA agent and I think they got CIA agent mixed up with like the elite of the elite soldiers. The other CIA agents that have clear shots at him from 10meters away miss wildly and so I can only guess they didn't get the same training.  I tried to soldier on through with the movie, accepting that this is the style they are going for and the hero is godlike but there was nothing to enjoy from the movie so I ended up having to turn it off.  The editing is in the fashion of a one shot but changes angles so often it almost feels like "Taken" or "Bourne Identity" levels of incoherence.
The action in combination with the camerawork was too much sometimes. The story is quite complicated and a lot of twists but it's a solid action flick. Adreneline rush as promised.

South Korean cinema, normally one of my favourites, but this time what a disappointment. It started all promising though, looked like it was going to be a spectacular and entertaining action movie, especially with the very different camera work. For quite a long time I would have scored it a seven, even if it was obvious that our local hero is unkillable, but that's a thing we're used to in this kind of action movies. But then the action scenes became so exaggerated that it got really annoying to watch, almost unwatchable. I get it that some reviewers didn't like the camera work, it was sometimes a bit sickening, but overall I thought this was the best thing about Carter. The story on the other hand is beyond ridiculous. You have to see it to fully understand. Action scenes that only would make sense if you were playing a videogame. And that's the feeling you sometimes get with this movie, that you're just watching somebody play a game. A game that I would play though, but as a movie it's a big no-no. There are plenty of passages that looked completely fake and that was also annoying. The acting was passable, that wasn't the problem. The longer the movie the lower my ratings got. From seven to six to five to four to three and that's just because of the spectacular camera angles. There's obviously going to be a sequel, definitely one I won't watch.

To start with the positive, I thought the way it was shot, as though trying to look like a continuous shot was interesting and well done. Some of the choreography made it seem like it was going to be a really good action film. However, as the movie continues, it becomes clear that they essentially ripped off Hardcore Henry and Shoot 'Em Up.  What really started to make the movie take a bad turn was eventually, the dialogue started to get really cheesy, like a bad voiceover of an old Godzilla movie. Add to that, some really CGI explosions and fire and it takes away from the film. It's as though they blew the budget on the editing and had a 12 year old add fire.

After the 1000th person got killed I was wondering when this will end.  Ultimately, a little boring toward the last third. Clever scenarios, interesting camera work and impossible but generally impressive stunts. But it goes on and on and on with a plot which is simplistic and sometimes confusing.  A primary issue was rickety camera work. Sometimes it was smooth, but much of the time shot stabilization wasn't implemented. Then combine this with the bizarre use of dropped frames, you get a highly annoying view of the action which often obscured the reading of what was going on.  Sure, have some crazy shaky hand held, but give the audience a rest with a higher proportion stable action images between the shaky parts.  It's an impressive effort but style was getting in the way of clarity.

If you're an action film fan watch this. The action is superb and I mean it. Very long sequences done as single shot action and its superb, violent and bonkers at the same time. Some of the camera movements are off the chart.  However, the film is let down by some dodgy acting, a bit of cheap cgi, way overlong in the 'dramatic plot' bits and ,strangely, some dodgy camera work in them.  Shot as a 'one take' movie but the director just gave up in the drama segments not even hiding the 'cuts' and saved his budget for the action. And what action it is!  Grab a beer or two and watch it for the truly sublime and, yes, bonkers action.  I hope action fans discover this and ignore the seriously low rating.  This is a film for action fans.

Not sure what they were trying to achieve with the camera angles and movement but 40 minutes into the film, I almost puked and had to stop watching. Its like Blair Witch Project. They could have settled for a conventional and smooth cinematography, but no. They seem to want to achieve something but failed. The intolerable cruelty of sacrificing viewer welfare by tormenting them with dizzying camera movements is unforgivable. The desperate attempt to stitch scenes and create a continuous shot was unsuccessful, it made me want to puke. And the American and Korean extras' acting especially during action scenes? Insufferable.  Good plot and action sequences though. But no, wont go back to finish the film.

Stupidity, indeterminate shots, crap cinematography, no plot to speak of... and yeah, Camilla Belle really needed a pay check. If you.re going to copy other films, at least do it well. This fails on all counts. Avoid it at all costs.

Looks and feels like a video game. Amazing action cut with brief exposition. Not a satisfying watch, 'couldn't finish it. I checked out when they used pigs to block motor vehicles. I know it's CGI but it's still a bit sick. Not for me.
Roller coaster of fighting scenes without respite. Almost like a VR RPG experience. Had to rest a few times to complete watching.... I could spend the time better with PC/mobile game. Poor!

Loads of action in this film and a big body count. The story was in it as well. Why someone ever decided to film it with drones and the picture is constantly moving, I have no idea. Hopefully someone can re-edit the film so it's a lot more still.

Plot is almost non existent Those drone shots are so distracting to know what is going on.  The camera work is bad, trying to one take everything with those Kingsman shot, but not even close to their level.  It hurts my head just watching this movie, this is the worst movie experience of the year for me hands down.

First off these types of insane action movies are my favourites the raid 1-2, kill bill, we come for the night, crank 1-2, old boy, upgrade, atomic blonde, John wick etc so this was a natural fit for me as I was super hungover when I put it on. The action is some of the best I've seen lately with wild gore how brutal the fights get and the speed at which it's done but is sadly let down to the camera being controlled by a cat with a Xbox controller other then that is a solid movie!!  Also why didn't he take her ear speaker on the bus that would've made sense?
Dont waste your time watching this movie the ending is horrendous the cgi is absolutely horrific close range hand combat was sick but that is the only thing good about this movie.

If you know what you are letting yourself in for (i.e. Mindless action, quite a bit of splatter and extremely cool cinematography) then this is it! The story is a bit haphazard and incoherent, but puts you right in the action and doesn't let you down or even breathe at times! Carter would love to be seen as one continuous shot, but the editing falls short at times. However, the cinematography effortlessly switches between life action and CGI (which is noticeable at times), but it doesn't take anything away from the fun the editors must have had putting all the scenes together. And yes, it feels like playing a slightly too long and repetitive video game, but you are still breaking the high score, it's engaging and a lot of fun!

Where do I begin.  Half the movie was filmed with go pros and drones. And the rest was green screen compositing.  The movie was "one take" where the camera does not stop or cut throughout the entire movie (but it does) they filmed it in such a way where you can purposely notice the cut and to eliminate some noticeable cuts, they dropped the frame rate to about 15-20 FPS. Where normal is 25-30 - it's just the style they aimed at. I wasn't a big fan of that style one take shot.  The movie made me nauseous and my right eye began to hurt. I'm not sure why my right one but it did.  The action would not stop which tired my brain a lot. There was to much information and was hard to process, hence why I got dizzy and my eye.  The ridiculous rating is a PHENOMENAL 10/10 - they should win an award for the most ridiculous movie made in history. It trumps the fast and furious franchise lol.  BUT due to the ridiculous level it made it fun to watch and could be classed as a comedy in some countries.

Could not find the proper words to tell/write how bad is this. I understand that Asian taste is different, but c'mon what is this??? A really bad video game, with poor CGI??  They found out this 'epic' horizontal three vehicles action platform, and they thoght its so unique it re-appears in every 10 minutes.  Zero star don't waste your time.

There are two main reasons for watching Carter, and the plot isn't one of them: the story is a confusing and forgettable mess, involving CIA agents, a deadly virus, tension between North and South Korea and a protagonist who has had his memory erased. No..the real reasons people will be checking this one out are the incredible 'one shot' direction (any joins hidden in editing), which sees the camera whirling in and around the frenetic action, and the amazingly over-the-top violence, countless bad guys dying in painful and bloody ways.  This kind of thing has been done before in Hotel Inferno and Hardcore Henry, with Hotel Inferno keeping matters to a snippy 80 minutes, but Hardcore Henry struggling at 96 minutes (the film also suffering from a weak plot). At over two and a quarter hours, Carter really outstays its welcome, despite upping the ante with each successive action scene. The clever technical camerawork is undeniably impressive, but it's not enough to hold one's attention for such a long time. To be honest, it all starts to get a bit boring...  So despite such wonderful moments as a bath-house battle that becomes a literal bloodbath, a fight that takes place between three vans moving at high speed, and an audacious finalé that features totally preposterous yet highly entertaining helicopter flying (achieved by some not very convincing CGI), Carter isn't quite the blistering adrenaline rush I was looking for: checking to see how much of the film is left is never a good sign.
It was the worse movie ever!  Just blood, and lots of fake action moves.  Imaginary moves were even worse than in Bollywood movies.  They even didn't notice to details.

I turned the movie off halfway through so I hope you can see by this mini review why I felt the need to do so, I am used to better film from Korea having watched for over 30 or so years....  I definitely give Byung Gil and all involved kudos for trying something different if a little "Hardcore Henry", unfortunately frame rate stutters, 70's style sped up vehicles and whatnot make the overall movie cheap.  Then the vertigo felt throughout the entire movie ends up getting more annoying and tiring than "cool".  Sadly sian cinema has been stereotyped to death with the western quality of actors they still get involved with as seen here from the intro. Mike Colter and Camilla Belle are fine but the rest of the western actors involved stick out like a sore thumb...  I think while doing something unique (ish?) the director forgot about including what should be standard in any film, a decent plot and if using a standard feasible story overall to still keep it reasonable believable.  Every action film doesn't need the "fast and the furious" in it.....or to be a video game either.  Sadly a turn off for me...

10star Actor:10 star 🎥:0 Star cause make me so dizzy  If they making for second part make sure dont use that kind of camera 🎥 taking action. The movie like cheap budget movie making not worth my time to watch it most of the fight part i skip cause me headache too much.

I have to admit, there are some amazing scenes that make you wonder how it was done, like the way The Matrix awed us with groundbreaking special effects long ago. However, it's a non-stop headache-inducing sequence of fight and chase scenes one after another, with handheld and drone camera work under constant motion that can be nauseating for some.  The fight and chase scenes are pretty amazing, reminiscent of John Wick, Bourne and Apocalypo in some ways, but with far less polished editing. I wish there was more story here with dialog, but it's just feels all over the place. It's more like a showcase of what can be achieved technically and cinematically than a complete movie. And perhaps the chaotic sequences can be attributed to the story's premise, but that would be a poor rationale. The story is just poorly developed. Some reviewers compared this to a video game, but there are video games that have far better storytelling.  Par for the course with English speaking actors in foreign films are the terrible actors, delivering terrible performances, as if they are reading from cue cards. You can usually ignore this in most foreign movies, but in Carter, English spoken roles and lines are a significant portion of the film.  Watch this if you are an adrenaline junky, and want to see some incredible action sequences. Otherwise, You'd be better off skipping it. This is not the best example of what Korean cinema can produce.
Many many agree, but the audacity of filling start to end with action should be applauded, agreed its not very believable but if you love action you won't mind..

Carter is an almost nonstop over-the-top action movie. The action scenes are really great and innovative. The plot is ok.  BUT this is the first time that I asked myself the question: Can there be too much violence in a movie?  Actually I think Carter is too violent. This is where I draw the line. More violence does not mean more entertaining.

No boring only action plus many thing's saved for sequel I guess The movie was great my expectations was low but the movie blew my mind.  I enjoyed the movie while watching I didn't expect too much action I loved camera work.

The action is pretty impressive, aside from a few bits that just arent physically possible and obviously badly edited. To start with when carter jumps through 2 windows and it looks like he teleports. Once he's inside, the yakuza bath action is actually pretty solid and exciting. Again later he just teleports to push Ha-na inside a van. Other than those few blips where it looks like he teleports, theres also the trash camera work, wobbly, shaky and doesnt focus on anything long enough for it to be examined. Also, nevermind currently watching and just reached a scene where somebody LITERALLY JUST FLIES out of a river. I mean come oon you were doing fine before, stop brealing the laws of physics ffs.

I've played some of the craziest VR titles and had dogfights in space.. been on rollercoaster rides while the body obviously is sitting still...  This movie tho...  Made me so sick watching it.....  The camera work/editing here.... wow!  Just wow.....  WOW!

Carter has an interesting premise, but that's pointless because the film is unwatchable. The camera work and editing are terrible. Every scene is unnecessarily jittery and strains your eyes as you attempt to keep track of the action. The jump cuts only make the experience that much worse. It was so disorienting I had to stop watching after 25 minutes. I'm not prone to motion sickness, but I felt queasy.  Do your eyes a favor and stay away from this ocular hazard. Instead, I recommend watching 1917 (2019) for some excellent camera work. And #Alive (2020) for a better viral infection/zombie movie.

This is just one of those things that if you're going to break something, do it in absurdly hilarious fashion.  1. No it's not for everyone.  2. The plot line is convoluted and non-sensical but that's ok because... 3. You'll be distracted by the incessant action.  4 Great locations and setpieces.  5. Creative shots and decent cinematography.  6. Too bad some of the.acting is wooden.  7. If you've got time to use up and brain cells to kill, this will be decent enough to pass the time. You'll either finish the movie or turn it off and do something else.

I really wanted to watch this movie, just couldn't last more than 10 minutes at a time with all the shaky camara work.  Ended up with a big headache after a couple attempts to watch. Would have been much more watchable if the film maker kept the camara steady.  Do not watch if you are prone to motion sickness.

On the whole, I suppose I enjoyed the film. I love Korean action movies, as they aren't afraid to push the bar when it comes to blood, gore, and sequences we've never seen before. At 2 hours 10 minutes, this is no quick watch, however. I won't rehash the synopsis as many reviews do, but make a couple of comments on the film in its entirety.  First and absolutely foremost is the direction and photography. The film was shot similarly to Hardcore Henry, but what I call one step removed. HH was shot first person POV. "Carter" (the film) is filmed like 1/2 step ahead of Carter the character; sometimes it looks like the POV is Carter's, other times the view is gyroscoping around him, while other times still the view is moving in sync with him but as if 3 feet in front of him. I didn't mind the multi-angular approach, but it made the entire film one big dizzying mess of discombobulatory explosions. Considering that I personally despise "reality films," first person films, or found footage pieces, I nearly gave up on Carter. With the sheer volume of action the film attempts to capture, this type of photography is a challenge to experience in a short film, let alone one one the length of Carter. It didn't help the POV (wherever it was) was shaky. Seriously...whoever edited this film should be given both an Academy Award and a massive kick upside the head & threatened w/ death if ever done again. I absolutely understand that part of this is the age old trick of covering up some faults and not being able to critically view some of the stunts and gore. If the film hadn't been shot like this, it EASILY would be rated at a 7 or 8 in my book.             Overall, if you can stomach a shaky multi-angled first-and-a-half person film, then you will have overcome one of the largest shortcomings.  Definitely has a lot of graphic violence as well as a bit of brief nudity. Language is mostly tame.

While agreeing on somewhat extreme superficial nature of certain action sequences Carter's cinematographic techniques induce the essential restlessness of Lee's journey to picture. What's problematic is the POV technique taking away the descriptive essence of combat scenes which in a way is also leaves the spectator wanting another round of watching. Plot is stuffed with so much detail that it could have been sorted in a better order. Skillful work by the cast in piecing together an excellent acting job. Great visuals and choice of surroundings with unique background audio. Carter is mission impossible thrown in to a zombie apocalypse which undoubtedly a great treat for movie fans.
Almost everything about this movie felt cheap, poorly executed and artificially acted. Some scenes are even comically poorly acted and the CG really does feel like it came back from the 90s.

The Camera Movement was a Bit of a Letdown. Carter would have easily be one of the best action movie in 2022, it's still a fun action movie to watch, The consent were outstanding, even tho we have seen a one Man Mission movie a million time, This was a whole new level of action movie.

There's an effort to make something fresh, with the camera.  The story is boring to death.  Back to the camera, it's a total mess.  Imposibles views or movement drives you like an insane roller coaster.  Ending to think: what happened?  Some actions are really too long just in order to make something impresive.  And 3 hours it's a lot...

It plays lie the cut scenes between gameplay of an action video game. A third/first person shooter. With about the same level of plot. While watching I was wait for an up arrow, down arrow X Y down arrow. B. Still it was action packed..

Carter's wife got shot while driving the jeep, I saw blood on the cloths and she is struggling to drive car with bullet wound. Next scene, she is fine, no blood in the cloths, she is back magically without bullet wound. No matter where Carter goes, middle of no where from parachute, endless city streets, there is always men in the corner waiting. How? Is entire country is against him? Another magic is lady on the phone seems to know all the building, random shop inside out. How?  Too much, did I say way Toooo muuuccchh Drone shot. Awesome fight scenes are ruined the experience by the drone. I can't seem to attach emotionally to any character, because of every scene is fight sequence. They want to use bikes, cars, jeeps, helicopters, train...seems they wanted to use everything is possilble. With the focus on drone and fights, they forgot the story. Some random characters talked about some randome dis on South korea and USA is not a story.  Carter is lost memory because of the device on his back of the head. Lost logic is memory is not stored there.  This is for mindless watching for teenagers.

How to make an action movie with no impact. Ingest some bad acting, plot incoherence a dash of 2000's special effect, a table spoon of « oooh music » Let it cook with a yo-yoing camera from left to right, up and down and back and forth.  Wait two hours, puke it and there you go, you've got a Carter.  Why a 2 and not a 1? Well because I'm sure there was some talented people involve in the movie, I just haven't found them.

Basically Korean version of Crank you'll find whether it's thrilling or dizzying. Applaud Jung Byung-gil's effort to made it look like one long shot with violent action sequences and dramatic revelations. Joo Won strongly played unhinged character from the start.

The plot in itself, is not the worst.  Could have been a good movie, if all involved was switched out with someone who knew what they were doing.  The start until end, makes me feel like im on a constant rollercoaster, after multiple shots of extremely sweetened high proof alcohol.  The monotone dialogues makes me want to just do a voiceover myself, along with the group of friends watching it.  Actors seem to have been pulled from the street, going by who was the dullest and most stereotypical for type of role.  All in all, save yourself from spending over 2 hours of what actually gave me nothing but dizzyness.

This is not a movie! It's a waste of all Human time and resources spent on production of this joke and waste of antibody's life who watch it even for a minute. This is like watching a friend play an action bloody Video Game that has all the weapons he needs and a coach telling him what to Due.  Unfortunately I dont play games and love my action Movies.

I gave this movie a shot cause the action was good but I can't watch it longer than 15mins I had to stop because I felt dizzy the shots was so shaky most of the time it felt like the movie was an earthquake with a magnitude that will knock you out in just 20seconds lol  Don't get me wrong I did rest in my first watch then sleep because of dizziness then I continued watching it but I really can't last longer than 15mins its not fair with the movie and the actor he was good such a shame.

The worst movie i ever watched, lost continuity full of headache not because of thinking about the story, but the animation is not blending with the project  Overuse, to much dramatised  I can even tell how bad this movie was, only 30 minutes since the movie start and i already had a headache 👏🏻

We need you to have the power to fly now or this scene won't work. We're also going to need these vehicles to drive themselves for a little while just so the main character can jump from one to the other as his dispatches the drivers.  I can't do it.  I just can't do it anymore.
